title: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Hi,as more people hop on the NS2 train, I thought it would be a good idea to do a kind of wrap up of all the great works that have been done by Nord Stage Classic and EX users in order to create programs that can be shared, both on request of others and just as a mean of sharing one's tweaking results.Going through this forum and some other places on the net, I pulled the strings together and put all the great programs and patches I came across into a collection where you can listen to them, download the program and find further information in the original discussions.If you only want to tryout the program files by yourself, you can download the whole set in the Downloads Section already here:200 Programs Collection 2009-2014However, if you first want to get an idea if a particular program might be useful of you, you find the whole set INCLUDING MP3 Previews on one page here: (Please be patient as the page might need up to one minute to fully load due to to the great number of small Flash Players, but if finally will load and once it is there, you can listen to all of them without further problems!)Nord Stage Classic/EX Program CollectionAlso, for each program there is a link to the post the program was posted first where you usually find additional info about how to use it or can ask the creator.It was great fun to go back to some of those programs to get some inspiration to play around with! So again, kudos to all the creators as mentioned there, and keep it up!It is unfortunate IMHO that the NS" does not understand the .nspg format, but maybe there is a solution sometime in the (near?) future.If you have any problem or issue with this page, find an error or want your program to be removed or changed, please PM me or reply to this thread!!Cheers,Johannes

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Is it possible to load any of these patches intoa Nord classic 76 rev b?  If so, how?

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Yes, of course. You need to have installed the usb driver and the Nord Sound Manager. If already done or when you do, come back here and we'll guide you to the rest of the process.Ramon

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Roman- I have both installed.  Do I just download apatch to my hard drive, and drag and drop intoSound manager?  If so, do I replace in the program tab?Do I need to delete a program first?

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Yes, you need to delete a program first, and you can drag and drop the file. To see where you can upload the program to the Stage you have to activate the "Organize" button.Ramon

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Where is the organize button?One other question.  Is it possible to split the keyboardUsing two program patches, or two piano patches etc.?

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: It's the first one on the left side.No, splits have to be done within a patch. In a patch you can split/layer any of the 6 sounds (or 8 if you count the extern section) you have at your disposal, that's, 2 organs (actually 2 manuals from the same organ), 2 pianos and 2 synths.If you are interested in having a split using one sound from a patch and another from any other, the only "help" you have is to save synth patches or to copy another's patch Panel A or B.... I hope it makes sense to you....Ramon

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Ramon- for example, could I have a EP from thePiano section split with another piano from the pianoSection?

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: yes, using the 2 panels from the patch.Ramon

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: not sure I understand.  Just got the keyboard and starting to learn.

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Indeed it is important to understand the basics, so the not too thick manual and two hours of time should give you a greatly improved understanding of your new instrument.As for the layer patches, activate both Panels by Pressing Panel A and Panel B buttons simultaneously, then activate the Piano Sections on both Panels.If you want to have a split, select e.g., a two-part split and select the Piano in one Panel for the lower section and the Piano in the other Panel for the upper part, should work easily!Cheers, Johannes

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: As Hanon said, there is no way of converting patches.The only way would be to manually convert the settings, or using a picture of the Panel (or a screenshot ofthistool with the patch loaded). Still you would need someone with a NS Classic/EX to do it and then dial in the settings manually.If it is one particular patch you are interested in I could do it (not all of them Im sorry..its a lot of work).CheersJohannes

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Hi Morgan,the NS EX patches are explicitly for the EX and Classic version of the Stage, so they should definitively work on your Nord Stage EX. No idea why it does not get recognized.You need to go to the PROGRAM section/tab in the Nord Sound Manager and then load the .nspg files, which should work (and there is no space limit, maybe you have been trying it in the Piano Sample Section instead??). A few sounds are Synth-only patches and come in the .nss format which has to be loaded in the SYNTH tab of Nord Sound Manager.Hope you get it work, otherwise let me know!Johannes

post_content: Use the sound manager to send the patches (nspg files) to your Stage. Read the manual or other posts to learn how to do it.If you still have then some difficulties, try asking more precise questions.Ramon

title: RE: Nord Stage EX/Classic Program Collection
post_content: Hi RamonSince posting I have virtually answered my own questions ...I have always understood (wrongly, it seems) that classic Stages were not capable of having external program files transferred on to them. My manual doesn't say much about it, only that factory programs can be restored via MIDI SysEx files. Right at the start of this thread, Johannes says "It is unfortunate IMHO that the NS" does not understand the .nspg format, but maybe there is a solution sometime in the (near?) future." (did he mean NS2 maybe??). Also the Nord website has a sample library, but absolutely nothing is available for the classic Stage except factory restore. All this only confirmed my wrong impression over the years.Anyway, now suddenly I discover I CAN transfer other people's .nspg programs to my Stage. This is great!!! But I was just wondering why I never knew before ...It's nice to have 200 programs available via this forum, but why can't Nord have in their sound library a whole bunch of patches for classic Stage models? Wouldn't that be relatively easy and a wonderful resource?Micky

title: RE: List of Nord Stage Factory Programs / Synth Patches
post_content: Asger Maltha wrote:Is it still possible to download the sounds from this list? I need the "Digilog Dual Pad" sound for my song...Hello, the Factory restore file for the Stage and other legacy keyboards is available on the Nord Keyboards site athttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/downloads/legacy-products. The file can be renamed with the "zip" extension to view and save individual files. Using Nord Sound Manager, select "Organize" mode, go to "Programs", and then save the program below to an open program slot (or delete a program you don't use and save the Digilog program there). Good luck!

title: RE: Just What I Needed - Cars
post_content: Surprised no programs turned up for this, but I just programmed the song on my Stage 3 recently and it should be easy to do on the Stage/EX (I don't have mine any longer).  The first synth you hear is a classic monophonic synth sound using a sawtooth wave but for the rest of the song until the end, a second monophonic synth sound is used with the square (or pulse) wave.  At the end of the song, the 2nd synth is used for a few bars and then joined by the 1st synth.  At the very end you can hear the difference in the vibrato/LFO used for each on the Stage 3 - for the Stage/EX, you may need to improvise with the pitch stick. Take care.Stage_3_Cars_Just_What_I_Needed.mp3

title: RE: Just What I Needed - Cars
post_content: I just upgraded my Electro6 for a Stage4 Compact and am learning how to download programs from this forum. Sometimes the Sound Manager will convert programs to the Stage 4 requirements, but sometimes they won't, and I can't access them from my downloads file on my PC. I'd really like to get the Just What I Needed program in a stage 4 format, or advice on how to convert from 2 or 3 to 4. Thanks!

title: RE: Just What I Needed - Cars
post_content: EllenDwrote:↑10 Dec 2024, 20:42I just upgraded my Electro6 for a Stage4 Compact and am learning how to download programs from this forum. Sometimes the Sound Manager will convert programs to the Stage 4 requirements, but sometimes they won't, and I can't access them from my downloads file on my PC. I'd really like to get the Just What I Needed program in a stage 4 format, or advice on how to convert from 2 or 3 to 4. Thanks!The sound manager does not convert programs from one Nord generation to the next, it only manages samples (and allows you to organize the location of patches/programs).You cannot convert from 2 or 3 to 4, there is no utility that will do that. What you can do, if the program uses a sample (and the sample is available) is load the sample on the stage 4 and recreate the rest of the sound using the synth controls with that sample.However, for the "just what I needed" sound, you can do that with the built in synth engine without the need for samples.here is a tutorial for the Stage 3 that you can adapt to the Stage 4.

title: loading a backup from a Nord Piano 5
post_content: Currently on a gig abroad and theyve given me a Stage EX and trying to load my snapshot backup from my piano 5. is this possible

title: RE: loading a backup from a Nord Piano 5
post_content: No. A backup from a Piano 5 will only load on a Piano 5 (73 or 88 keys).You can extract the samples and piano samples out of the backup just by renaming it to a ZIP file. But that's all. No programs transferable.If it's really a Stage EX, it won't even play samples through the synth engine at all - only organ, pianos and synth. A Stage 2 EX will do.

title: Compatibility NS Classic/EX (nspg) and NS2 (ns2p) patches
post_content: Hi,since I have received a couple of questions regarding using patches between the classic/EX and Nord Stage 2, just a few words.Since Nord introduced a new file format with the NS2, basically the patches are not interchangable. That is, NS2 owners basically need to create their patches "from scratch".I think the main difference are in the Synth section which required the new file format, which makes sense given the greatly enhanced capacities of the NS2 (just look at the file size: 426 vs. 547 bytes). Subsequently the Synth Patches (.nss) cannot be used on the NS2 neither.So if one really needed to carry over a particular patch the easies would be having both instruments and just copying all settings "by hand" on the front panel. Given the easy layout of the Nords this should be quite easy while only having the nspg file will not allow you to do so.So I would say sorry for the moment at least, but .nspg patches are EX/Classic ONLY, and vice versa.Still maybe it could be technically be possible for NORD to develop a converter for the PC which would convert classic patches into NS2 ones (obviously one would loose the ES/Classic only features (OK the only one I can think of is the LOW/HIGH EQ in the Synth section).If one were crazy enough to look into the NSPG file format one could maybe reverse engineer the format.Basically, the NSPG patches (426 bytes) seem to contain in total MAX(!) 16*20 Offsets, i.e., a maximum of 81920 bits of information content, so by (a hell lot!!) of trial and error one might find out which byte=00 switches to 01 if, e.g., Piano Section A is enabled etc.Here is an example of the Hex view for one patch, you can see the magnitude of 00 and 01 while for quasi-continuous values the coding requires even more guess work.patch_hex.png (32.07 KiB) Viewed 30154 timesBut I honestly don't think it would be very useful!Moreover, playing around with the values could seriously damage your very valuable and thus expensive instrument!! Not to mention you' lose any warranty!!After all, the Nord Stage is very easy to program and create patches "on the fly" so for me there is no point in messing around with the great stuff provides us with.(Now if I were to buy a Kronos with its basically fullfledged PC inside running some kind of a linux derivative it might be another story...)But maybe Nord COULD release a small utility to convert CLASSIC/EX patches into the .NS2P format (if and only if it is technically doable)! It would IMHO be a great recognition of the Classic/EX line in this sense maintaining backward compatibility!But for the time being, there is no way around it, so you have to ask someone with a Classic/EX to tell you the settings of a particular patch and dial it in manually!Cheers!

title: RE: Compatibility NS Classic/EX (nspg) and NS2 (ns2p) patches
post_content: The problem is that the files contain a checksum I cannot figure out how to calculate. I've compared several files and the "checksum" always changes when changing a parameter. Without the checksum being correct, the sound manager refuses to load it into the Nord Stage.

title: RE: Compatibility NS Classic/EX (nspg) and NS2 (ns2p) patches
post_content: Of course the checksum will differ if you change a parameter. But different manufacturers compute the checksum differently (eg, including all sysex or just the data bytes, then added up and compute the checksum as the "result modulo 128"). The best way is asking Clavia directly. They should provide that information as it is no trade secret, but a functionality feature.

title: OB-8 and JX-10 Brass Patches
post_content: I watched a video with an OB-8 on it to try to get the brass sound - it still needs some tweaking but it's easy to modify as needed.  I noticed on the video that each note starts out being out of tune and then settles so I tried to get that affect. For this program the TIMBRE CONTROL gets set slightly above 0 to be slightly out of tune initially with the true note. The MOD ENV REL/DECAY determines how long it takes for the two "oscillators" to come together and filter to close to end state. The MOD ENV ATTACK is set about 10 o'clock to open up the filter. The LP FILTER FREQ CONTROL will adjust how much contrast you want between the sound of the filter at its most-open point and the filter at the end of the decay. The LP FILTER FREQ will determine somewhat the midpoint of the filter based on the range set by the FREQ CONTROL.  The mp3 covers the initial patch, adjustments to the parameters above, then addition of echo and reverb for a quick "Jump" rendition.OB-8 Brass     W.nspgOberheim OB-8 Brass Patch(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2756 timesNordStageEX_OB-8 Brass Patch W.mp3This next one I put together this evening based on the JX-10 brass on SoundCloud - playing with the EQ and filters can bring out the midrange a little if needed. B has a Wurlitzer with brass fading in.  Similar to the OB-8 patch, simply playing around with the few parameters noted can yield a nice range of sounds for the brass you're looking for.  Take care.JX10 Brass     W.nspgRoland JX-10 Brass (A) Fade-in Brass (B)(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2599 timesNordStageEX_JX-10 Brass W.mp3

If not, is there any way to see what settings are in a nss file so that maybe I could create a stage 2 synth sound similar?Thanks,DaleHello dcraftfrombr,Welcome to the forums.Hi Dale,As near as I can remember, these were the settings:NS2_Patchsheet_Notes_b_NBAR.PNG (59.49 KiB) Viewed 24447 timesThis should at least get you part of the way there.Unfortunately, there isn't a good way to view the settings, or load a .nss file into the NS2.Important factors for the sound are:Mono (lead synth-like)Saw wave oscillator waves.at least two oscillators tuned an octave apart.24db/oct LP filter with resonance tuned up very high.a bit of glide to slide between notes (think Minimoog!)Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: how to load a nspg file into a new Stage 3?
post_content: You cannot - it’s not possible to load programs from other versions of a Nord

title: do nspg files work on newer nords
post_content: im planning on getting a nord electro 6d, i was wondering if nspg files are going to work on them

title: RE: do nspg files work on newer nords
post_content: nspg files are program files for the Nord Stage they will not work on any electro instrument. In fact there isn't any cross compatibility of program files between any Nord series 1x to 2x to 3x

title: Patch request for: Rocky Mountain Way (Joe Walsh)
post_content: Hi everyone!I need to figure out this one. Particularly, the wonky synth patch during the bridge, which you can hear in the left channel here:Don't confuse it with the talk box in the right channel.Besides the straight up bass guitar, there's a left hand synth doing some "bass work" and there's the right hand synth doing some bluesy grooves.1) are both hands using the same patch?2) anyone want to take a stab at making that patch, or suggesting how I can do it?I have an NS2, but I think if you give me an NS3 patch I'll be able to inspect it with the Viewer and port it over...Thanks!!

title: RE: Patch request for: Rocky Mountain Way (Joe Walsh)
post_content: Sorry in advance for not answering your specific question: When we covered this, I just used a clav patch in the left hand, which adds crunch without sounding like an electric bass note. Part of this is philosophy: as a keys player I don't like to get into the bass player's space with my left hand playing, and since our covers band has a solid bass player that makes my desire to stay out of his way a strong one. When we covered this, I did not even play bass notes (using my Electro's clav patch) for the whole song. Instead I only added it for those places in the song where I wanted to effectively press the "More" button. I guess the direction you take might depend on to what degree you like how your bassist plays.

title: RE: Genesis Follow you Follow me lead solo patch please
post_content: This is the sound you want.  Add chorus to one bank and phase to the other.  Reverb and compression.

title: RE: Genesis Follow you Follow me lead solo patch please
post_content: There are no strings.  Hammond organ with left hand and ARP Pro Soloist with the right.  For Hammond you want Leslie with 0 drive, slow, chorus (V3) and phase (of which you'll have to choose between the lead and the organ).  Good luck and enjoy!

title: RE: Strings
post_content: HelloIf you have the classic Nord Stage (or EX), then you should be able to find some useful patches here:nord_stage_program_collection.phpSome of the programs has a MP3 attached so you can pre-listen to to sound.

title: RE: Strings
post_content: There are no real string samples (nor the possibility to add one) in the Stage Classic and EX. Only synth strings can be achieved. For real strings and horns you need to get at least a Stage 2 or hook up an external synth or module via MIDI.

title: RE: Van Halen For Stage
post_content: Hi,there are some programs for Stage2 and Stage3 available in this forum, but nearly all of them are based soley or partially on samples which will not help on the Stage Classic. There is one Stage2 program which is solely based on the synth engine of the Stage2:post4143.html?hilit=Halen%20Love#p4143This cannot be loaded into the Stage Classic unfortunately because programs cannot be shared between different generations of a Nord keyboard. However, when loading the Stage2 program into the Nord File Viewer app athttps://ns3-program-viewer.herokuapp.com/it will show you the synth settings. I don't know the synth capabilities of the Stage Classic but you may try to re-create it.It looks like this for Panel A and Panel B, I would just give it a try:WhyLove1.jpg (194.23 KiB) Viewed 9118 times

title: RE: Nord Sample Library 3?
post_content: 1- Reading the manual of your Nord2- checking Clavia's website3- downloading the Nord Sample Manager4- Reading the manual of the Nord Sample Manager

title: RE: Nord Sample Library 3?
post_content: Spider wrote:1- Reading the manual of your Nord2- checking Clavia's website3- downloading the Nord Sample Manager4- Reading the manual of the Nord Sample ManagerQuote, let me just add that to learn just how to upload existing samples 1 and 2 are enough, since 1 explains also the basics of Nord Sound Manager which is all you need to download sample to the NS3 (but the order is fundamental, so #1 first and  I'd enforce it with a little addition as"Reading thewholemanual of your Nord")

title: 14 Classic Rock and Other Patches
post_content: I have wanted to post for quite awhile, and now that I'm selling my Stage EX to get a Stage 2, I figured it's either now or never.  This post has nine programs followed by a reply with another five.  I hope some of you find them useful.  Thanks.Update: If you're interested in just the Synth patches, the second page (eleventh post) has quite a few from the Programs below.Pedal Steel patch with Wurlitzer that I put together for the Pure Prairie League song "Two Lane Highway". The mp3 has another player fading in on Rhodes and then me following with the Pedal Steel.TwoLaneHighway W.mp3Two Lane Hwy.nspgPure Prairie League - Two Lane Highway - Pedal Steel Guitar(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2426 timesPatch for the Intro to the Styx song "Too Much Time" covering both parts.Styx TooMuchTime W.mp3Styx TooMuchTime.nspgStyx - Too Much Time - 2 synths(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2459 timesAnother Styx patch for the song "Renegade" covering the Hammond with overdriven Leslie and Synth after the guitar solo.Renegade Styx W.mp3Renegade Styx.nspgStyx - Renegade - Organ and Synth after Solo(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2392 timesIn the 80s I had a Sequential Circuits Prophet 10 that was an incredibly flexible dual manual synth. A favorite patch back then used a square wave with pulse width adjusted to sound somewhat like a clavinet - this one comes close to my Prophet and then some with the addition of effects, organ, strings and clavinet sample.NordStageEx_SynthClav.mp3Synth Clav.nspgProphet Synth Clavinet(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2340 timesAlways love a blues harp - this one has a bit of distortion:Harmonica Blues W.mp3Harmonica Blues.nspgBlues Harmonica(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2600 timesI put this patch together for a song by EastSouthern called "Whisper" - though it sounds heavy in effects, it fell right into the song well. "Studio Grand 2 YaC7 Sml 5.3" was used for the piano. Listen through the end.EastSouthern W.mp3EastSouthern.nspgEastSouthern - Whisper(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2547 timesI'm not sure if the original Billy Joel tune "She's Always a Woman" had a background accordion, but I like this patch putting one lightly with "Grand Lady D Stw D Med 5.3".ShesAlwaysAWoman W.mp3ShesAlwaysAWoman.nspgBilly Joel - She's Always a Woman - Piano and Accordion(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2467 timesI tried to get close to the 12-string sound for Hotel California with this program while using one of the Synths for bass:Hotel Calif W.mp3Hotel Calif    W.nspgEagles - Hotel California(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2611 timesI know, I know - there are quite a few Van Halen "Jump" patches posted - I tried to capture the slightly decaying volume and closing filter as notes are held with this one.Jump Van Halen W.mp3JUMP Van Halen.nspgVan Halen - Jump(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2658 timesMORE PROGRAMS IN THE POST BELOW

title: RE: 14 Classic Rock and Other Patches
post_content: Here are a few more - take care.Steve Miller Band's "Jungle Love" intro - 3-split program.  The lowest split is the first synthesizer, start with the "REL/DECAY ENV MODE" at about 9-10 o'clock and hit/hold two adjacent notes simultaneously, then slowly turn the knob clockwise to slow down the pulse.  The middle split is the synth "whistle", hit quickly as in the song.Jungle Love W.mp3Jungle Love.nspgSteve Miller Band - Jungle Love - Intro 2 synths(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2276 timesJohn Prine's song "Hello Again" has a great Wurlitzer in it with a very "flutey" Hammond sound - the synth section is used along with the organ to get close.Wurlitzer Hello W.mp3Wurlitzer Hello.nspgJohn Prine - Hello Again - Wurlitzer and flutey Organ(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2275 timesEmerson Lake and Palmer's "From The Beginning" has nice synthesizer solo in it.  This patch uses both synth sections to get the sound.From the Begning W.mp3From the begning.nspgEmerson Lake and Palmer - From the Beginning Synth(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2248 timesThis patch covers the Organ and Synth in "Abacab" from Genesis.Abacab Genesis W.mp3Abacab Genesis.nspgGenesis - Abacab - Organ and Synth(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2414 timesGrand Funk - I'm Your Captain (Closer To Home) - Strings and Surf - The mp3 starts with the programmed settings and then changing just the filter resonance and frequency gets the strings effect later in the song.Im Your Captain W.mp3Im Your Captain.nspgGrand Funk Railroad - I'm Your Captain - surf and strings(426 Bytes) Downloaded 2184 times

title: RE: 14 Classic Rock and Other Patches
post_content: I have a Stage 3 now, and similar to how one spends time trying to recreate a Prophet 5 or Oberheim sound that a song just doesn't sound "right" without, I've found I've done the same doing my best to recreate the Stage EX sounds I used for "Whisper" by EastSouthern. EastSouthern was a great three-piece group (guitar, bass, and drums) that played locally and put out a compilation of original songs on CD in 2012. Using my Stage EX I added a keyboard to their song "Whisper" a couple years later for the drummer/singer/songwriter Keith Elsbernd. Demonstrating the flexibility of the Stage EX, what you hear in the song is a single take with no overdubbing of the various sounds used. It's simple, but I've been hooked on the Nord Stage keyboards ever since.  The program can be found at the top of this post. Take care.EastSouthern Whisper W.mp3

title: DX-7/FM piano patch
post_content: Hi all,for those asking if it's possible to create a DX-7/FM piano patch on the Nord Stage, here's what I've created:DX7 FM EP - NORD Stage Demo.mp3DX7 FM EP.nspgAlex's DX7 FM E-Piano Patch(426 Bytes) Downloaded 3920 timesComments welcome.Alex

title: RE: DX-7/FM piano patch
post_content:
Wow that's amazing! Thanks a lot Alex! Was looking for a FM EP sound for a while.Just have to wait until I am near my Stage to upload it. But it seems you mixed an EP with FM right?In any case, its excellent, immediately reminds of those 80ish stuff!!!Looking forward to surprise/shock(?) my bandmates playing George Benson's "Nothing's gonna change my love for you"....EDIT: While studying FM synthesis, I came across the "original" FullTines Patch developed on the basis of Yamahas FM Synths which can be regarded as THE DX EP Patch.The settings can be found here:http://homepage.ntlworld.com/steve.sims ... rhodes.gifAll six operators are used but three carriers with one modulator each (Algorithm No. 5 at the orig. DX7)Code:Select all+<---+
     |         |         |    |
   +-+-+     +-+-+     +-+-+  |                                                      
   | 2 |     | 4 |     | 6 |  |                                                      
   +-+-+     +-+-+     +-+-+  |                                                            
     |         |         |    |                                                   
     |         |         +----+   
     |         |         |   
   +-+-+     +-+-+     +-+-+                                                               
   | 1 |     | 3 |     | 5 |                                                               
   +-+-+     +-+-+     +-+-+                                                               
     |         |         |                                                   
     |         |         |
     |         |         |                                                   
     +---------+---------+                                                             
               |So in theory, using both Panels, one should at least get the belly attack and normal "body" tone while missing only the slightly detuned body sound.Will see if that gets somewhere. Now probably Alex patch is the best one can get given the limitations of the Synth, so it is basically just for understanding and practising FM synthesis after having gone through the theory and the maths.

title: RE: DX-7/FM piano patch
post_content: Hi folks! I'm new to this forum and have recently downloaded all the sounds you guys have created and posted here.So now I'm going to share what I have done so far.FM synthesis is a very exciting thing.Since I once had a DX7 in the eighties I do remember how the typical FM-epiano sound was constructed.As Johannes showed us it consists of three modulator-carrier pairs.One pair creates the body of the sound which is the result of a modulator-carrier frequency-ratio of 1:1.The modulator's envelope generator sets the time variant modulation intensity which leads to a frequency spectrum that can't be created by subtractive synthesis, no matter how complex the basic waveform may be.This part of the sound can in deed be reproduced by the Nord Stage and it sounds more or less exactly like the DX7. It's just the very sophisticated key follow parameters that the Stage is missing.The modulation intensity is controlled by the Timbre parameter.The DX7's second modulator-carrier pair usually does just the same with only a little detuning.This can be simulated by the Stage's unison function.The third pair now is responsible for the bell-like attack sound that made the DX7 famous.It's the result of a modulator-carrier frequency-ratio of 14:1.Unfortunately the Stage doesn't offer this particular ratio.The highest possible ratio is 9:1.To add at least this one you need to use the synth section of the other panel.(Since 9:1 doen't exactly produce a perferct bell character try and switch this panel one octave higher.)No matter how authentic you might think this sound is it's still very suitable to be added to a grand piano sound for pop piano styles.If you are in need of a synth pad background sound after you have frittered away both panels for the DX7 emulation just misuse the Farfisa. It sounds not really good but acceptable at a pinch.Let me know your opinion ...Taenzerin.mp3Grand + DX.mp3DX7-II.mp3

title: FM "pulse"
post_content: Hi everyone!Hope you're all enjoying a lovely weekend! I was wondering if anyone could help me with the Synth section on the Nord Stage 2ex? The band I'm in wants to use the Sin sound from the FM library (in the OSC section) so that it keeps "pulsing" throughout the song while I change notes and staying on the beat. But sometimes it starts playing off-beat.. What can I do to keep the sound on the beat? (I've set the Shape to 0.0)Any help would be gratefully appreciate it!Best,Lauren

title: RE: FM "pulse"
post_content: There are only a couple of options to make this work.1. You actually play the notes that make the pulse2. the clock driving the speed of the pulse has to either be synced to or from a master clock that also drives or is driven from a click track.

title: Splits and layers on EX88
post_content: Greetings,new here.Second post.I often do a trio with keys/drums/guitar.In smaller venues it's all the budget will allow.Started using an EX88 in 2010,a rental from a national music chain with a lot of use that I bought,well used.The retailer sent it through 'Backline' for a going over before I made the deal,I'm happy.I often use synth bass split low at E3 and layer piano/organ above.Very intuitive and easy to operate.Writing my own bass sounds has been most satisfying,and actually prefer the synth on the EX to the '2'.Not much for using samples,and the synth on the '2' just didn't excite my ears like the EX still does.The synthon the '2' tries to do what my Roland XV3080 does,but not as well IMO. Keeping my EX.Now that I can operate both 'panels' I'm able to layer another synth above E3 for leads or pad/comps.A typical setting involves waveform 39 or 44 for my bass,Rhodes shallow or Wurli,and the B3 organ.Sawtooth pads or square comps/leads is what I do most,the EX is great for someone who prefers to writetheir own sounds IMO.Interested to hear from anyone else using an EX to play blues,R&B,classic rock,jazz in a 'lefty bass' role.

title: RE: Looking for Europe Final countdown patch
post_content: Hi,long time havent messed around with that one. IIRC, they used a layered FM style Synth Brass patch (D50 or Yamaha) with an Analog Sound.Here is a very first try based on a layered P and S Wave.Use the MOD Wheel for the more Pad kind of Sound throughout the Song after the hook line!!But for sure the brassy element could be done better.And once again, sorry for the crappy playing!Final Countdown.mp3

title: RE: Looking for Europe Final countdown patch
post_content: I thought I'd give this a try also.I had a little different perspective on it.In the original recordings' sound, I hear a dual sound "certainly multi-element" consisting of a fairly standard Roland JX-8P analog spit brass, combined with different Yamaha TX-816 brass elements. It sounds like one of the sounds has either a pitch envelope or glissando "Yamaha DX/TX" which causes it to slide up to the note.In my patch attempt, I made a judgement call that the brassy lead was the strongest, most recognizable part, and concentrated on it.The synth section of the NSex lacks a pitch envelope and polyphonic glide. The only thing I could think of the fatten it up was to make a mono lead version of the horn sound, alter the attack slightly and add glide.You folks can be the judge as to whether it works or not. Since I used both synths for the horns, the pad is conspicuously absent.Countdown123.mp3countdown Horn.nssFC_Synth_horn(53 Bytes) Downloaded 918 timescountdown lead.nssFC_synth_L1(53 Bytes) Downloaded 924 timesFinal Countdown.nspgFC_patch(426 Bytes) Downloaded 1108 times

title: RE: Looking for Europe Final countdown patch
post_content: Hi everybody,Here's another attempt at the infamous brass riff.You can get a pitch envelope by using the Sawtooth Detuned (Sd) waveform (in the analogue section) and modulating it with the Mod Envelope.Getting this one dead on is probably not possible with the NS by itself. If you can layer it with an FM brass sound, that would probably work wonders for it, as the other guys have already noted.CheersLeoFinal Countdown.mp3

title: PF - Shine On You Crazy Diamond
post_content: There has been some time since somebody shared a patch for this great song, so I decided it was time to share my take on it!!Part I– Use the MOD Wheel to smoothly increase the volume. Aftertouch shoud add vibrato on the long sustained notes, but it adds tremolo (sorry, I don’t like how the vibratos start on the synth section, change it if you want)Crazy Diamond I.mp3Crazy Diamond I.nspg(426 Bytes) Downloaded 722 timesPart II– I’ve always been asked to play everything that the others band members couldn’t, so here’s the other guitar during the lead guitar solo.Crazy Diamond II.mp3Crazy Diamond II.nspg(426 Bytes) Downloaded 621 timesPart IX– I started here, I really love this part, so peacefull and inspiring!! Here the main synth should sound more like a real horn, at least to my ears, and that’s what I tried.Crazy Diamond IX.mp3Crazy Diamond IX.nspg(426 Bytes) Downloaded 698 timesI hope you like it!!

title: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: AFAIK, the original keyboard rig consisted in a CP-70 with a phaser, a Hammond and the MiniMoog typically used by MM.Not perfect but a first try. I use the 2nd panel just for the synth slide (a bit difficult to switch between), but ok if you have band that "fills" the void ;-).blinded_by_the_light.mp3[youtube][/youtube]

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: Hej Johannes.Sounds good:)I'm not a Manfred Mann expert at all. But it sounds to me like the intro sound is not played on the CP-70. It seems to me, that it is played on the hammond with added phaser. The organ is two-manual, so the intro sound is probably played with left hand, while playing the other organ stuff with the right, before it shifts into the synth stuff.Later in the song at 4.48 you can hear the cp-70 more clearly and it sounds nothing like the intro-sound.I tried playing the organ with phaser and it sounds about right to me.Just my thoughts. I might be wrong of coarse. You can try it out and see what you think:).Have fun. And thanks again for making this nice forum.Sebastian

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: Hi Sebastian,I had exactly the same feeling that it was probablymor an organ based sound (probably some transistor model), but then it just didnt sound "right", and after some researching I found among others this discussion:http://www.the-gas-station.com/messages ... days=40204&which basically argues that it was a CP-30 AFAIK, MMEB used at least the CP 30 and an CP 70, but it is really hard to tell in the end.

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: Yeah okay. Then it probably was a cp-30 with phaser, but I don't know much about that sound.Unfortunately we don't have the cp-30 sound on the stage, so I would probably use the organ with phaser or perhabs try wurly.The sound is closer to hammond than the cp-80 imho.What do you think?Nice find with the article. :)

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: Just an update: It might back in the 70ies have been more likely a Rhodes, as it can be seen e.g. here:So I created an updated patch with the following features:Panel A: Rhodes w/ Phaser (Intro) and Organ (Use MOD Wheel to morph between the two sounds)Panel B: Moog kind of sound with portamento for the Glide, Aftertouch controls the Vibrato towards the end.Sustain is activated only for the Synth so you can play the Glide than sustain, switch the Panel anc continue playing while the synth still sounds.

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: Yeah thats seems right. Good job. :)

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: Wow, I am really impressed by the sounds you created. I am pretty sure that in the mix (e.g. in a live situation) nobody could tell the difference with the original.Good work!

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: I'm no expert but I've always thought the intro was a Rhodes piano with a phaser effect, it sounds like it's being doubled up an octave apart (like two rhodes sounds layered an octave apart with a phaser......whatever it is it sound really great and is one of the greatest rock songs out thereI'm just trying to get this sound on my NE 5HP which is how I ended up on here

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light
post_content: I've had success with this song using a very perc-heavy B3 sound - with almost all the drawbars off, and then combining it with a rhodes underneath.DH

title: RE: Manfred Mann's Earth Band - Blinded by the light

title: RE: JON LORD - PERFECT STRANGERS
post_content: As I mentioned in my original post, there's nothing clever in this patch.Drawbar setting: the bottom four drawbars (16', 5 1/3', 8', 4') all full on. All the other drawbars completely off.No Vibrato or Percussion.Rotor on, and the Drive (distortion) to about 8.No effects, the sound is completely dry.I also have the Keyclick set to maximum 10. On the Electro, I'm guessing that that would correspond to Key Click level (in the B3 Menu) of H2. That's just to add a little treble to the sound. You could also just add a little treble from the EQ (say about +2 or+3)A few things to note:I don't know if the Drive is the same between the Stage and Electro, so you may need different settings. But basically you add as much Drive as you can until just before it starts to sound mushy or indistinct.Finally, a lot of the sound is how you play the chords. This is vitally important. Generally for this style of playing, you don't play the third of the chord, only the root and fifth, or root, fifth and octave.You can also add deep single notes or octaves in the left hand.So, for example, to play C major, you might play it as CG, GC, or CGC in the right hand while playing C two octaves down from middle C in the left hand, or CC one and two octaves down from middle C. This gives the chords the extra growl and bite.Generally, you would just adjust the exact right hand notes to get the effect you want. Playing lower in the right hand makes the sound thicker and stronger, but might conflict with the guitar player (although that's not usually a problem with a Blackmore-style player). Playing higher will make the sound thinner and weaker, but will be heard more clearly in the mix.BTW, if you're playing the riff for Hard Loving Man, it will always sound weak and thin by itself. The trick is to add the root notes of the chord in the left hand at the same time, three and a half octaves below the riff.

title: Analogue Synth Programs & All secrets behind the NS Synth
post_content: Hi,after browsing a lot trough all kinds of web pages regarding synthesizer programming, I still felt the need fo getting more into ACTIVELY getting all out of the Stage's Synth section (the analogue part, so far) and I bought a copy of the Welsh's Synthesizer Cookbook (http://www.synthesizer-cookbook.com) in order to start from scratch to build some programs for the Stage starting by replicating his suggestions. The major aim of this exercise are toget good patches that somehow replicate natural instrumentsGet a deep understanding of the Analogue Section of the StageSee how far you can get with the Stage's "limited" Synth capacityHopefully get together some kind of reference/database of what you can do with the NS SynthWhile the Synthesizer Cookbook is covering only analogue substractive synthesis, I would also be interested in FM and the Wavetable engine but postpone that for the moment.So far, I have been mainly experimenting and somehow created some sounds I really liked by tweaking-as-you go, I hope to get a better understanding of substractive Synthesis and as a by-product some useful sounds out of the Stage.The limits of the Synth are mainly that it only has two Envelope Generators with moreover only two parameters and the limitation to only one oscillator (you get two only with sawtooth). The latter can be overcome by using the two synth sections simultaneously which is why I will post the results as complete programs (.pgm files).If you are interested or have any comments or your own experiences, feel free to post them here.Johannes

title: RE: Analogue Synth Programs & All secrets behind the NS Synth
post_content: I am very much interested in these synths programs, as I am using my Stage also for a techno live-act.I'm working on some synth sounds myself, and having these could be of lots of help.do you have them available for download?thanks in advance

title: RE: Analogue Synth Programs & All secrets behind the NS Synth
post_content: Hi there,so it took me quite some time to figure some technical stuff out about the Analog synth in the Nord Stage. But after doing some calibrations, FFT analysis etc. I finally have the tools layed out to start building the patches.Note that while I've played shortly at friends' places e.g. a Moog and others, I am not an expert of Analog Synths. So reading Welshs Cookbook (http://cgi.ebay.com/WELSHS-SYNTHESIZER- ... 918wt_1037) was really a great inspiration and helped me a lot. Still, the following might be a bit too technical for complete Newbies, while for sure completely obvious for Analog Freaks (who hardly would by a Nord Stage for its Synth I guess...). UPDATE: Here you can now find a PDF version:http://synthesizer-cookbook.com/SynCookbook.pdfFor those completely new to this stuff,http://www.soundonsound.com/search?url= ... ummary=Yesis a good and huge reference if you don't want to invest in a book.It is basically my experience in the quest to get EVERYTHING out of the NS Synth. For the farer future, I am planing on buying a Moog LP or Voyager, but given I just spend a fortune on the red beauty, this has to wait, so for the moment I stick to learning and getting all I can out of the Nord (starting to understand the values of all the parameters etc.).In any case, any ideas, own experiences, critics are highly welcomed, in particular since IMHO the manual is not too informative on the Synths capabilities.The basic things you need for creating some nice Patches with an Analog Style synthesizer are two oscillators, Filter, Envelopes, LFOs and some additional small tools. Given that the Nord Stage Synth engine is kind of stripped down compared e.g. to the Nord Lead, I had to figure out how to overcome some shortcomings. Moreover, the Documentation in the Manual is not perfect as in particular the settings for the Timbre control are not well documented so I had to measure them myself.In the following I report my findings which I am currently using to build some patches of natural instruments as well as recreating some classical Analog synths.1) Oscillators:Typically, two oscillators will suffice for most basic jobs.(a) non-synchedThe basic ones used are the Sawtooth(S), Pulsewidth(P), and triangle(T) forms along with noise(n) and SINE(C/ turning Timbre to zero).However, only the Sawtooth is available also with two oscillators (Sd). In this case, the relative pitch of the second osc can be adjusted with the timbre know where 0=-1Octave, 5.0=equal, 10.0=+1Octave, i.e., one semitone equals 0.42 on the scale. On top, the oscs can be detuned up to 10cents using the UNISON knob. Shortcoming: the level of both oscs is fixed and equal.The T & P oscillators don't allow two different oscillators at a time. One method of overcoming this limitation is using both Synth sections of Panel A & B at the same time which allows at least to detune the oscillators by +/- 1 octave (e.g. for a Marimba sound). You have a second option if you need the oscs only slightly out of tune using the UNISON knob in its first half of the range which allows adding a second oscillator up to 10cents out of tune.RemarksThe Pulsewidth Waveform is important and the pulsewidth can be adjusted by the timbre knob where 0.0=50% and 10.0=1%, i.e. increasing the value by 1.0 decreases the width by 5% (e.g.,20% width would be timbre=8.0).A Sine wave is not directly integrated. You can use the "C/" waveform but i found that it has a very strong second harmonics and weak 3th and 4th, no idea why. Another option is the FM program 1 with TIMBRE set to zero which looks/sounds more like a true sine wave, or lastly:Use the NOISE generator, Resonance at 10.0, 24db Filters and adjust the frequency to the desired tone (Set the Cutoff to 330 Hz (i.e., the cutoff frequency shown in the display is the one applied if one plays the note E1) if you want to play the notes as if it where a Piano (A1=~A1). While not being a perfect sine, this allows on top using the keyboard track buttons to create a oscillator which is independent of the key you play (which on a traditional synth you can select using the KeyTrack switch and is useful for some sounds).]The last point is also a way of having e.g. a Square wave on one Synth and mixing it with a Sine with continuosly varying relative pitch as is needed for a variety of sounds!So how to calculate the Cutoff frequency if you want the Sine, say, a fifth that is 7 semitones (dx=7) above the other, fundamental pitch? Just calculate it as  330*(2^(dx/12)) Hz, e.g., for a fifth over the fundamental pitch (=7 semitones), just set Cutoff=494Hz.(b)synchedThe Stage features a second oscillator for creating hard-synched sounds which can be created on any analogue >=2 Osc oscillator by swithinc Sync ON, so in this case we are fine with the stage. The timbre know in this case controls the pitch of the synchronized osc (thus changing only the color of the tone, as the main pitch is controlled by the Master osc). Using the timbre knob you can set the pitch of the slave osc (which must be higher than the Master's pitch). At 0.0, the pitches are equal, at 3.8 the slave's pitch is one octave higher, at 7.6 it is two octaves higher, i.e., one semitone equals approximately 0.3 on the scale.FiltersObviously there are a wide range of filters used in analog synths, still, the LP is by far the most common so the NS does a good job in this section.Envelope GeneratorsYou get basic stuff with the Nord Stage, but it suffices for most what I am currently looking at: an AEG and FEG with two adjustable parameters each. Obviously, the classical 4 Parameter ADSR envelope would be nice to have but I can mostly live with it.The only "real" shortcoming for me is if you want an LFO you cannot use the FEG at the same time.LFOsAt the beginning I did not quite use it a lot but after working a lot with the Synth section, I now consider it really well done by CLAVIA to squeeze it in the Stage.IMHO you have several LFO options on the Nord Stage(a) Vibrato/Pitch-LFO: The vibrato Switch allows to set some basic vibrato which can be set to 4-8Hz in ths SYSTEM menu and is triggered differently. If you want it always, assign it to the Wheel and always have it up.(b) Tremolo/Amplitude-LFO: Using the Tremolo effect gives you this effect when set to the Synth section(c) But the most important LFO (and the one most likely to resemble a "real" one) is the repeat mode of the Filter Envelope Generator. By adjusting the Attack and Decay Value you can create basically anything between a triangle and Sawtooth waveform. If you want to set it to a particular frequency, knowing that frequency is just the inverse of time, compute f=1/(t_Attack+t_Decay). So if you need an LFO of triangle waveform with 10Hz, you need a cycle length of 1/10=0.1Seconds implying 50ms for both Attack and Decay.This LFO can than be either used to control the Cutoff frequency (WahWah, for this, you could also use one of the WahWah FXs) or the Timbre Parameter of the oscillator. In particular, when applied using a Pulsewidth Oscillator, you have PulseWidthModulation(PWM)!The restWhat do classical Analog Synths have on top of these basic tools? You might find the UNISON feature which enriches the sounds by adding slightly detuned oscs, which the NS has integrated, a Sample&Hold Waveform which creates computer-type sounds (NS doesn't have one), Glide/Portamento (NS does), Legato/Mono/Poly modes (as well), Ring Modulation(see the FX section) and switching Keyboard tracking on/off (can be somehow replicated using the Noise generator with fullResonance).Bottom line, the NS is for sure not the most tweakable VA on the market and has certain limitations (Most importantly, not all osc combinations/tunings are possible, only LP filter and only two parameters per Envelope Generator). However, after working hard on replicating several sounds I heard from classical Moog etc. Synths I must say that you can do still quite lot. On thing however is to interpret the values of some of the knobs since they are not always meaningful and have to be calculated in order to get the desired result (e.g. detuning a second sawtooth e.g., 7 semitones).In the following posts I will upload some of the results I obtained using above descriptions in recreating some "classical" sounds.UPDATE: An updated version of this post can be downloaded in the downloads section:Nord Stage – How to use the Virtual Analog Synth

title: RE: Analogue Synth Programs & All secrets behind the NS Synth
post_content: Thanks for that, it is definitely usefull to know. Althogh I have until know used mainly my hearing in order to get a desired sound, rather than theory to replicate or make one.Also of note are the envelopes, they are actually quite cleverly made, specially for the LFO like Env. Wile you can only control attack and rel/decay, you are able to put a sustain, which lasts for as much as you keep the key pressed (I find it that only in this case the Env really does release), you are also able to set it to simply attack and decay. This is due to the fact that both the AEG and FEG have something called ENV MODE, which is selected by pressing shift and moving the decay knob, and looking which one is lighted up. Each have a third mode, on the FEG, you have the LFO like feature while in the AEG you got an envelope shaped differently, kind of a middle ground between sustain and simply decaying, almost like a piano-like envelope.Gus

title: RE: Analogue Synth Programs & All secrets behind the NS Synth
post_content: Hi Johannes!I know you wrote this six years ago, but maybe you can answer a few noob questions about a formula you used.You wrote something to the effect that, if you want a harmonica sound (1), you must calculate the cut-off frequency needed to detune the sine wave dx=8.05 (2)(3) above the square wave. Calculate it as 330*Exp(0.06*dx)Hz. (4)(5) For a fifth over the fundamental pitch (7 semitones), just set the cut-off frequency to 502Hz (6).(1) Is this information from a recipe in Welsh’s Synthesizer Cookbook?(2) What does “dx” refer to?(3) Does 8.05 mean 8 semitones and 5 cents?(4) Did you use 330 because you set the cut-off frequency to 330Hz earlier?(5) What is “Exp”?(6) How did you arrive at 502Hz?Thanks!

title: RE: Analogue Synth Programs & All secrets behind the NS Synth
post_content: Hi,you're right that is confusing. I fixed it, but actually a better version of this description can be found in the download section:Nord Stage – How to use the Virtual Analog SynthBasically, it refers to creating synth sounds with two detuned oscillators using the noise generator with full resonance  which basically creates a sine wave and then the cutoff sets the frequency. The formula just computes the frequency from the desired interval. dx=7 semitones means a relative difference in frequency of (2)^(7/12)=1.49 so that the frequency of a fift is 49% over the fundamental. Since 330Hz at the Nord is calibrated to sound like A4 (or that the cutoff displayed is the one applied on the note E1 (obviously the cut off frequency varies across the key range unless keyb tracking is completely disabled, so the displayed value needs to be choosen to represent one key), you need to increase the cut-off fequency to 330*1.498=494Hz to have the sine sound one fifth over the fundamental (e.g., piano sound or second panel synth sound).In the welsh Cook Book they give many sound description containing two detuned oscillators (e.g., by 8 semitones and 5 cents for the harmonica sound), which can be programmed roughly this way.Sorry if it wasn't all clear.(Note: Exp would be the exponential function, but technically it's a twelfth root, fixed in the doc. The 502 Hz is the value for 8 semitones and 7cents (not 5, sorry my error) (approx) indeed and refers to information given in the Welsh Cook book, see here:harmonica_synth_welsh.png (53.31 KiB) Viewed 10290 times

title: Jamiroquai Rock Dust Like Star Intro Synth
post_content: Hi,Does anyone have an advice for a sound to use for Jamiroquai "Rock Dust Like Star" intro?I'm just beginning to learn...Thanks,Fabien

title: RE: Jamiroquai Rock Dust Like Star Intro Synth
post_content: What gear do you have to use?Jamiroquai keyboardist Matt Johnson uses an Alesis Andromeda A6, Nord Wave, and Rhodes EP live. He appears to use the A6 for the sound live, but the same sound can be created with the Nord Wave.The synth patch itself is very simplistic. It sounds like he's using an 8' saw wave single oscillator "or no detuning if multiple oscillators" through a 4 pole lo pass filter with the resonance turned up very high, but not to the point of self-oscillation.Overall the filter cutoff frequency is primarily being modulated by sine, or triangle wave LFO with a very slight amount of slow decay envelope.It's a sound that you'd expect from a vintage minikorg 700s, or similar synth.I have found the following site to be very informative for synthesishttp://www.beausievers.com/synth/synthbasics/

title: Organ Sound Dance Across the Floor
post_content: Hi,working on Jimmy B Horne, Dance Across the Floor. Anybody got that sexy organ sound or can give me tips on how to create it on the EX?thnx!!

title: RE: Organ Sound Dance Across the Floor
post_content: I would suggest starting with the first two drawbars at 8, the 2nd OBOES at 3, the 5th TRMPS at 8, the FLUTE4 at 8, Leslie On, C3 Chorus On, and Percussion On with the 3rd Harmonic.  The percussion volume can be set to "soft" if it's brighter than you want. I'd play with it from there - it sounds somewhat "hollow" so you'd want to leave gaps between drawbars used. The EQ/Amp can also help with getting a sharper edge to the sound as well.  Good luck!

title: RE: reverse piano on NSEX
post_content: Hi,1. Are you looking for synth section settings to imitate that sound ?2. Otherwise there is no reverse piano sample for the NS-EX, in "npno" format.3. If I remember well, that kind of sound has been released by someone on the forum, but in the  "nsmp" format, thus compatible with some other Nord keyboards.4. You may have a look at effect processors, some guitar players have "reverse effect" on their pedal board.Cheers,F.

title: RE: reverse piano on NSEX
post_content: Can't be done through the NS-EX as it lacks standard sample imports and there's not a Nord Piano library version.  Use the synth section, create the envelope first (slow attack, rapid decay, no sustain, release to taste depending on whether you want it to continue after you let go of the keys, max if you do, min if not).  If you have a separate filter envelope, get the filter to open up slightly as the sound is held down.Then explore the wavetables as your sound source, and find something that sounds right.  Unlike a regular piano sound, the attack is not perceptually that important, so you may find something unexpected works well.Sorry I can't be more specific, I lack any kind of Nord Stage to try this on, but what I've said should work on any Nord synth with wavetables.Al

post_content: Hello forum.I am new to Nord Stage EX, never tried a synth or e-piano in my life before…But I have read the manuals for EX and Sound Manager.I have used Sound Manager for backup, uploading, downloading program, delete, rename etc.So many hours spend to help my girlfriend, a classic educated pianist, to get two “good sounds” from Nord Stage EX, in two KB Zones.We have tested a lot and did find two great programs in this forum.A – Supersonic (Dual Panel with two KB Zones)B - VIVALDI_STRINGS (Dual Panel with two KB Zones)From Supersonic I want the lower end, from Vivaldi_Strings the upper end.After trying and reading – can’t join two programs into one, so at last I took a photo of the front panel, each for the Panel A and Panel B of Vivaldi_Strings.So starting with Supersonic , moved the Zones in both Panels, and started with the upper Zones for Vivaldis two Panels.But I can’t get the sound of Vivaldi_Strings. title: RE: Best of 2 programs into 1
post_content: I do not have a NS EX, so I cannot try, but if the 2 slots overlap somehow, depending on how the programs are made, there might be no way of doing what you want. You might need 4 slots.

title: RE: Best of 2 programs into 1
post_content: Hi Sveinpetter,Mr G. is almost certainly correct, but failed to elaborate in a way in which you, as a novice to this instrument, will easily understand.Each Panel (renamed to "Slot" in the Stage 2) contains a maximum possibility of three onboard sound engines: an organ, a piano and a synth.  Thus, with two Panels/Slots one has a max of six onboard sounds happening at once.  It will be HUGELY important for you to fully understand this in order to fully understand the instrument.I do have an EX but frankly don't feel like going to trouble of loading these programs right now (it's past 2am here) and anyway you will gain more knowledge and understanding from doing this for yourself...To determine whether your desired "mega-program" will be possible, first examine the SUPERSONIC program's basic settings on each of the two Panels.  Don't sweat the details right now.  All you need to know is which instrument sections are being used in the lower zone of the program to produce the sound you want.  Be sure to check both panels.  Now switch to the VIVALDI program and do the same thing for the upper zone.  Please send us the results of your exploration to continue this analysis in detail......but in the meantime, let me create an illustrative example which may help you: suppose that SUPERSONIC uses both a Panel A synth and a Panel B synth in the low zone, and that VIVALDI uses both a Panel A synth and a Panel B synth in the high zone.  That's four synths and you only have two to work with in a single program.  That's what Mr G. meant by "you might need 4 slots" (keeping in mind that what Nord used to call a Panel is now called a Slot)  Conceptually he is right about that, but that's not particularly useful to you because the instrument does not have 4 slots/panels -- it has two.Successful "marriages" between two programs will always hinge on one major consideration: can the entirety of each individual sound be produced in full with the available sounds at hand: two organs, two pianos and two synths.Hope this helps...if you'd like specific analysis on your specific scenario, please post back to the forum with the internal details of each  of the two panels for each of the two programs -- what instrument sections are required to produce the sounds you want, and we can offer specific advice on your desired situation.  (if need be, I can be cajoled into loading those programs into my EX...)Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Best of 2 programs into 1
post_content: Thanks a lot to Mr_-G- and pablomastodon!Let me guess pablomastodon, you must be a teacher….“,with two Panels/Slots one has a max of six onboard sounds happening at once”“That's four synths and you only have two to work with in a single program”“Successful "marriages" between two programs will always hinge on one major consideration: can the entirety of each individual sound be produced in full with the available sounds at hand: two organs, two pianos and two synths.“I do now understand, and will stop trying to do impossible settings.Yesterday I downloaded Ctrl and Patch Editor to get all the settings in a program to recreate them in another program, but I guess I stop that too.Have not access to the EX before the weekend, so I can’t give more details now.Again, thanks.

title: RE: Best of 2 programs into 1
post_content: Hi,More of a student than a teacher, but find that I learn things more deeply when attempting to teach them, so I have personal benefit, too.First I heard of Patch Editor and will have to go check that out, but you may find that CTRL will still be useful for "dissecting" programs and learning how different sounds are created, most especially within the Synth Section.  The newer NS2 has the ability to easily tell you the exact parameter setting for any knob, but that was developed after the Classic/EX went out of production, so CTRL may be the best tool for that.Happy Nording!Pablo

title: RE: SAX synth sound on Nord Stage
post_content: I thought I'd add something to this old thread as I feel the original reply by ZeroZero is a bit discouraging.It is pretty much impossible to get anything remotely like a sax using a conventional synth like the one on the Stage, that is true. However, lots of people get perfectly good sax sounds by using samples, so all you lucky Stage 2 owners should be able to do this fairly easily. There are a few very clever synths, such as the MOSS board for the Korg Triton series, that can do pretty good sax sounds as well. So don't give up!

post_content: pablomastodon wrote:A breath controller with a midi interface can connect to the Nord's midi input port....PabloAnd probably to the Control Pedal port too.I have an old DX7 breath controller somewhere, I wonder if it is possible to make it work in the NS2 with some modification.

title: RE: SAX synth sound on Nord Stage
post_content: Well, I found this:http://www.retrosynth.com/~analoguedieh ... roller.jpgOne problem is that the breath controller is fed with 9V and outputs about 5V.I thinkthe expression control connector provides 3V.If I feed the breath controller with two 1.5V batteries instead of -9V, it still works and outputs about 3V, but not sure how well it works (my digital tester is slow updating the voltages). However I am not sure if the expression pedal expects a voltage between 0 and 3V or what. I am hesitating to try this and damage something. If anybody has a better idea of what goes on at the expression pedal port, please let me know.

title: Patch of: Bon Jovi - Its my life?
post_content: Hello,I would like to play Bon Jovi - Its my life, and I trid to make patch for NSEX. But it is not so good.Can anyone help me create patch, where is- piano sound: song intro- some kind of "machine start" soundin song intro- background vocal/voicesthanks

title: RE: Patch of: Bon Jovi - Its my life?
post_content: I'll see if I can find my patch, but I had to do this for a band when I had my NS Classic (I'm now using NS2). I also use a Nord Wave so my patch wouldn't automatically work for you, but you might be able to use some of my ideas.For the opening sound, to supplement the drums, I sampled a range of drums and reversed them on my computer before loading them on to my Wave.  I then layered this with my NS piano in the bottom octave.  I used panel B and the middle zone for a second piano sound running through the tremelo and amp sim to do some shaping with the EQ for the little arpeggio type hook at the start.  In the chorus, I switched to a new patch layering an untreated piano and a choir sound from my Wave.  In the second verse there is a filtered drum sound at the start, so again, back to keyed sampled drum hits on the Wave using the filters.I know you can't do what I did on just an EX, but suffice to say, even with two keyboards, I had to make careful use of the zones plus two separate patches on both devices to make it work.  It was well worth the effort though as it really rocked!  Shame I only dep'd for that band a handful of times.

title: Nord StageEX - Samples you may like
post_content: HelloI recently had a request to share some insights into how I achieved some sounds on my new album, so I've decided to post them here for other users to freely use too.Here's some Nord info from a few songs on the album:* Song 07 "Defining Moments"I created an arpeggio rhodes sound on one of the tracks in this song. This sound uses the EP3 Mk11 Shallow rhodes.* Song 11 "Rustic Road" -PIANO: is the Studio Grand 2 YaC7 with onboard EQ set to: Treble -5.5db, Mid 0db, Bass +1.5db, Reverb: Stage, Dry/Wet 2.5, String Resonance: ON.ORGAN: is the B3 with various settings (attached 14.3 Organ - MASTER)PAD: this was a sound within Logic using the EXS24 "Big Pad MW" plugin* Song 13 "Resonance"* LEAD: (attached 16.2 Lead&Chords)* PIANO: this was the Studio Grand 2 YaC7 with above EQ settings + arp settings (attached 13.2 UROG)* ORGAN: same as above (attached 14.3 Organ - MASTER)Overall, I used plugins on the album to achieve the smooth pad sound. However, I've attached another sample (19.6 Pad ATMOSPHERE), which is the best smooth pad I've been able to achieve on the Nord.We had to do some EQing within Logic, to mix the album and pull down some of the MIDS and LOW MID frequencies. On top of that, the album has been professionally mastered, to smooth out some of the harsh top ends and bellowing bottom ends.I've learnt a lot through the recording process and still have many things to learn ahead in future projects.You're able to check out the 13 x track album samples at:http://www.traceychattaway.comOR you can listen to full length samples athttp://traceychattaway.bandcamp.com/.Thanks for allowing me to share and I hope some of you find the samples helpful.Kind regardsTracey ChattawayOrgan - MASTER.nspg14.3 Organ - MASTER(426 Bytes) Downloaded 983 timesLead and Chords.nspgLead and Chords(426 Bytes) Downloaded 884 timesPad ATMOSPHERE.nspgPad ATMOSPHERE(426 Bytes) Downloaded 1029 timesUROG.nspgArpeggio/ping pong Piano(426 Bytes) Downloaded 802 timesWalk On.nspgArpeggio/ping pong rhodes(426 Bytes) Downloaded 841 times

title: RE: Nord StageEX - Samples you may like
post_content: Hi PaulI've just seen your message today, so apologies for only responding now.I hope you've enjoyed some of the patch samples and managed to use them all ok on your Nord Classic.99% of what you hear on the album I created note by note, including the subtle background arpeggio-type sounds, using my Nord EX. I did route everything through MIDI, in order to save and create loads of ideas whilst composing songs. This way I was able to quantize the arpeggios and experiment with different sounds, before finalising each individual recorded track. The pianos were "live" but were also recorded via MIDI. I changed my mind several times about which pianos samples I wanted to use and was also able to use the smaller file samples loaded on my EX while composing. When outputting final recordings I uploaded the XL file sizes to my Nord, one by oneMy first Nord was the classic, and then I upgraded to the EX a few years later, so I currently have enough memory to load some of the XL pianos. Mind you, it still doesn't seem like enough memory any more, as I have to continually delete and upload the Nord piano samples (depending on the song I'm writing). I don't regret buying the EX, as it was the best that Nord had on offer at the time. It's only now, that they're creating bigger file samples, I'm beginning to feel the age of my EX. However, I bought it with the intention of keeping it for decades .......in 50 years these original Nords will be sought-after classicsIt would be brilliant if there was a way to connect an external hard-drive/flashdrive directly to the EX/Classics, so that the memory capabilities wouldn't be an issue.Can you load any of the XL files onto your Nord Classic? Are you doing some recording yourself?Kind regardsTracey

title: RE: Nord StageEX - Samples you may like
post_content: I seem to remember reading somewhere (in the Nord site?) that in L and XL the quality of the recording and layers are the same, there is a difference in where string resonance is mapped to.

title: RE: Nord StageEX - Samples you may like
post_content: I believe that what Mr G says is almost correct. From the Nord Webpage:The Extra Large versions are fully mapped accross the keyboard which increases the size a bit. The velocity layers are the same as on the other sizes.The Large versions have String Resonance samples all across the keyboard, providing you with a very full sound.Meaning that the XL really has one sample per key. But if the mapping was done correctly and the piano was in tune, you shouldn't really tell the difference.Still the upgrade to NS2 is definitely worth it. I went from 1 YamBright SML, 1 QueenUpright SML, 2 EPS, 1 Wurly, 1 Clav, 1 Harpsichord to 3 LRG Grands + CP80, 2 Med Uprights, 6 EPs, 1 Wurly, 1 Clav and I still have some mb to spare.Saludos,Gustavo

title: RE: Quiet/Still/Warm Pad Patch
post_content: ricochet wrote:Hi Hanon,You don't happen to know how to use the pianos (downloaded files) off the Nord website do you?  I first deleted some of the keyboard's pianos, and then loaded 1 or 2 of the new pianos (very large files!) into the Nord Sound Manager - but I think I'm missing a few steps as I can't see any programs on the Nord keyboard to play them with (and the existing piano sounds that I deleted play nothing - understandably)...Richard/RicochetHi Richard,If your NSC was connected when you moved the new pianos into Sound Manager that should have started a 6~10 minute process of loading the sample into the instrument.The Nord pianos (.npno) should be thought of as a building block, but not so much as a program.If you'll go to one of your existing acoustic piano programs, you'll probably find more than one of them with the "type" red led number flashing now (by the dynamics button) When you hit the dynamics button without the shift button, it changes the acoustic piano sample associated with the current program to something that's in your instrument.The alpha-numeric display should momentarily display the name of the piano sample then revert back to the program name.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Quiet/Still/Warm Pad Patch
post_content: Hanon,I really like this sound.Can you give me some tips on how you programed it on the NSEX so I try on the NS2 synth please ?

title: RE: Quiet/Still/Warm Pad Patch
post_content: frantzkb wrote:Hanon,I really like this sound.Can you give me some tips on how you programed it on the NSEX so I try on the NS2 synth please ?Hello frantzkb,It's a deceptively simple pad based upon two saw waves "same octave" with about 4 cents of detuning.4 pole low pass filtering, full keyboard tracking of the filtering with the resonance turned up enough to give it that juiciness.The amp envelop should have a soft attack and 0.5 second release.As an option, I use the aftertouch (AT) to introduce the slightest amount of filter cutoff sweep.Also you can introduce LFO modulation of one oscillator to enrich the chorusing effect of detuning.Stereo reverb and chorus is also important. However, if over-applied, pins the sound squarely to the 1980sI hope this helps.I remember reading an interview with a keyboardist like Steve Porcaro where he said that when he got a new synth, the first thing he did was dump all of the factory programs and start programming sounds from scratch.This was a "sink or swim" method of learning a new piece of gear, the first 10 or so sounds were really difficult, but, by then you began to really understand what made your synth work, and the panel became more intuitive.Cheers, Hanon

title: 80s Sawtooth / Van Halen Jump Patch
post_content: I created this patch for Van Halen's "Jump" but it can be used with a variety of 80s songs that have that big sawtooth mix sound.  I threw in some light organ in the upper key split and some light acoustic piano in the lower key split to fatten up the sound a bit.  I also have the modulation wheel set so that it will fade the volume to zero at full deflection (for an easy way of fading out or trailing off).  The attached .mp3 contains the intro and synth solo for "Jump".Jump Intro 2.mp3

title: RE: 80s Sawtooth / Van Halen Jump Patch
post_content: Your Jump patch is really quite similar to the original Jupiter patch. Your performance ... very good.José Luis from Barcelona.

title: RE: 80s Sawtooth / Van Halen Jump Patch
post_content: Jump was most probably recorded with an Oberheim OB-X not a Jupiter. Almost certainly the synth on record's intro "1984" was an OB-X. Live Eddie Van Halen used an Oberheim OB-Xa.

title: Progressive 70's rock Organs and Synths
post_content: Hello all you awesome users of this forum!I recently came back and tried out some of the latest sounds uploaded here!Im very impressed! : )When im making sounds im often afraid of the organ part of my stage ex!For some reason it always ends up sounding like those cliche "Hockeymatch" organsIm looking for the organ sounds produced by analog organs in the 70s!If anyone has sounds to upload, or tips to give on how to "wield" the organ part of the stage like a boss, i'd very much appreciate it!Here are some examples of the organ sound i would like to haveCamel - Another night:<--- The organ sound that plays throughout this whole songEloy - Journey into 1358:http://grooveshark.com/s/Journey+Into+1358/3X0ak2?src=5<-- Organ sound primarily after the 1:10 markPink floyd - Echoes:<--- Love this organ!Camel - Rhayader goes to town:http://grooveshark.com/#!/album/The+Snow+Goose/2528056<--- Can anyone achieve the organ sound in the solo part of this song ? (around 2:40m)Also from this song i would like the synth sound at around 1:27m! So awesome!Thanks in advance for all your help!/Adam

title: RE: Progressive 70's rock Organs and Synths
post_content: Love those songs. Never heard of Eloy, but the others are some of my favorite pieces!! Unfortunately I'm in a jazz band and when I do get to play progressive rock the project is abandoned due to lack of guitar player....Still, might have a look tomorrow to see if I can get close results. Most of the Camel stuff is not hard to achieve, but it will unavoidedly sound different. Keep in mind its not about getting the sound 100% replicated. Because different gear sounds different. You do not know which Electric Piano Bardens had, or even if he had a B3 or other organ from hammond. As credited, he had the following in the Snow Goose Album:  Peter Bardens:	 Organ, Mini Moog, Electric Piano, Pipe Organ, Acoustic Piano, ARP Odyssey       So in other words to sound exactly like him on that album you must have exactly the same gear. But since that is near to impossible my opinion is that most synth sounds must be an aproximation. But organs can be almost duplicated.Also, here is an excellent page with midi files for camel:http://web.agria.hu/kepenu/camel.htm

title: RE: Progressive 70's rock Organs and Synths
post_content: I was in a Camel Cover Band some time ago, and we did cover Rhayader goes to town. From what I remember, Peter Bardens' Hammond was almost always 888800000, no percussion and absolutely no C/V. In some songs or during the solos you can grab the other drawbars to taste to be more prominent, or use the eq with a little more overdrive.With another band I did cover Echoes, but I wasn't pretty satisfied with the organ sound, but 888800000 is always a good start for any rock tune. Add the other drawbars to match the sound you are after.The Eloy organ seems not to be a Hammond.Ramon

title: Intro synth "Who are you" by "The Who"
post_content: Hi there,I would ask if anyone of you have never try to re-create on a Nord Stage EX the synth used in the intro by "The Who" in "Who are you".I'm trying by myself but the synth is quite strange in my opinion.If someone have already done this sound and want to share it will be great also any suggestion for start to develop the sound is appreciated!I report the link of a Youtube video with the synth, piano, acoustic guitar and claps isolated in the song.

title: RE: Intro synth "Who are you" by "The Who"
post_content: Turns out it's a guitar, which is why it's difficult to do on synth.To clarify, here's a description of how it was done:http://www.thewho.net/whotabs/gear/guitar/history.htmlwrote:An overdriven ARP 2500 or ARP 2600 synth. The overdriven guitar is fed into a voltage-controlled filter (VCF), which is being controlled by a low-frequency oscillator (LFO) triangle wave. The LFO is set to the tempo of the song at eight pulses per bar, making the tone of the VCF rapidly rise and fall in time with the song. The next step is to make each pulse from the LFO to trigger sound alternately from the left and right sides of the stereo picture.

title: RE: Intro synth "Who are you" by "The Who"
