The overdriven guitar is fed into a voltage-controlled filter (VCF), which is being controlled by a low-frequency oscillator (LFO) triangle wave. The LFO is set to the tempo of the song at eight pulses per bar, making the tone of the VCF rapidly rise and fall in time with the song. The next step is to make each pulse from the LFO to trigger sound alternately from the left and right sides of the stereo picture.Thanks for the answer... Now I reached a sound which is close enough to the original for my purpose.I'll try to re-do the sound with the Motif-rack so I can use the guitar as base.Regards,Francesco

title: RE: Can Nord Stage EX synthesizer simulate an Arp Omni?
post_content: To all,this is a deceptively hard challenge.Here's what I came up with.ARP_PATCH_DEMO.mp3ARP Solina.nss(53 Bytes) Downloaded 672 timesBy all means, don't stop here!I'm sure someone else can do better.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Can Nord Stage EX synthesizer simulate an Arp Omni?
post_content: Can it make any kind of noise like the low notes in that video? Yes - I haven't had my EX long but have been messing around with the SYNTH section. After you get the tone you'd like to play with, one way is to work with the MOD ENV and LP Filter sections to get the effect. Hold the SHIFT button down and then turn the REL/DECAY ENV MODE in the MOD ENV section until both lights indicate the REP function is active. Release the SHIFT button. Turn the ATTACK and REL/DECAY ENV MODE in the MOD ENV section to about 10 o'clock (turning counter clockwise speeds up the repetition). The ATTACK control can be adjusted to whether you want a sharp attack in the repetition trigger (turning toward 7 o'clock) or something more like a sine wave like what's heard in the video. Both controls should be worked with to set the speed. The FREQ CONTROL VELOCITY and FREQ controls in the LP FILTER section can be adjusted to define how much sweep there is between the high and low thresholds of the repetition. RESONANCE in the LP Filter adds another dimension to the sounds but you have to be careful, it can be like feedback and blow out some serious low frequency pulses in the REP mode - work at low volume until you know what you have. I'm sure those more familiar with the SYNTH section may have some short cuts too. Good Luck.

title: Nord Stage Classic - Which sounds to load?
post_content: Hi Folks,I am new to Nord and trying to understand how/where I can download sounds/programs from? Am particularly interested in hammond sounds! Is my kit too out of date to down load these sounds from the nord website? When I down load from there to my mac and try to add to my Nord sound manager the actual sound will not show up which makes me think they are incompatible with my Nord? I know it is discontinued but loved it when i played it so went ahead with the purchase - seems a bit of a shame if I cant access certain sounds - any help appreciated?Thanks,G

title: RE: Nord Stage Classic - Which sounds to load?
post_content: Hi G,Your Nord Stage Classic can certainly load additional sounds: First of all, you can load all Pianos from the "Nord Piano Library". Second you can load programs/patches from Nord (basically only the Presets), but also user-created programs (such as the ones found here:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord_stage ... ection.php). They are in the format *.nspg and you have to load them using the NS Manager downloading them to the PROGRAM tab.You can NOT load samples though (.nsmp files) either user-created or from the Nord Sample Library.But for Hammond Sounds you should be easily able to load some other presets from the Collection linked above. It might be a good idea to check if your OS is the most recent version (v5.04, check after switching it on in the display).Cheers!Johannes

title: RE: good horn section patch - help!
post_content: A good horn section can be almost impossible to create from scratch - a synthesised sound won't cut it, so usually you either have a sample you like or you don't. In this case, you might be better looking through other sample libraries until you find something you like, then converting/importing it into your Nord (assuming your Nord can play samples). If your Nord can't play samples, you may have to look to another kbd to get what you want, I'm afraid. (I have a Stage 88 Classic and I wouldn't even try to get a horn section sound out of it, my Korg Triton does that job).

title: RE: good horn section patch - help!
post_content: I bought a Yamaha Motif es rack that I'm really enjoying hooked up to my Nord stage EX for under 500 on ebay. There seem to be a lot samples of all kinds of instruments. In the performance mode its pretty easy to layer multiple horns and tweek them to your liking.   And even though I don't use the drum samples out live they are great to practice to. Also The Nord with its assignable foot pedals does a nice job of switching and turning on and off the arpeggios. And with all the sounds you can layer with the Nord plus the sounds from the Motif rack make for some really fat textures.

title: RE: good horn section patch - help!
post_content: Hi Vinny,You won't get the kind of horn sounds you are looking for out of a Nord.  i have tweeked the 'Brassy' patch on my Nord Stage and really fattened it up using 'delay' and 'detune' etc.  It is ok but thats as far as it goes really.  You sound like you will be needing doits/bends/falls etc.i still use an EMU ULTRA sampler (which can read Wav. files).  It is old but still great.  i run it thru a Lexicon MX Reverb module (as all my samples are 'dry'). i only use about 5 x brass samples but i reall love them all (and use them all the time).  i picked it up an ebay a couple of years ago for about £350 (and sellers very often include huge libraris of samples).  i midi this up to an M-Audio controller keyboard on gigs.And i have a Roland JV1080 (as TomS suggests) and this is a fantastic 'all round' module.  i think the Brass sounds (and everything in general) are far superior to the popular Karg Triton.  They have a great cross section of analogue thru to orchestral brass and you can buy expansion boards for around £80 on ebay.  i midi this up to my Nord also for strings/choirs which layer well with the Nord pianos.Or if you have the money, the new TYROS 3 is totally out of this world and completely blew my mind !!Hope this helps dude.Best,monsterjazzlicks

title: RE: Al Kooper organ sound
post_content: Did you know...?Turning on a B3 is a bit like starting a jet engine and isn't as straightforward as turning on a Nord:Al Kooper said that if the Hammond wasn't already turned on at the famous Highway 61 Revisited sessions he wouldn't have been able to play "Like a Rolling Stone"...He had never played a Hammond before and didn't know how to turn it on!

title: How to Heavy rock guitar synth Ex
post_content: Since it is challenging , here is a simple way to make a heavy rock guitar synth sound on your nord stage Ex.Select the 94th sound called 1st quarter under the synth catagory.If you do not have this sound download it from the attachments.Turn the Freq to 2.0 Khz.Next turn the resonance nob to 1 and a half.Then then selct A-Wa2 in the Effect one section.Adjust the amount to 52 and the rate to 47.Now set the Hall soft setting in the reverb section and turn the reverb nob to 6.set the Compresser to 7.2  The sound is almost done!To add distortion select amp one and turn the distortion nob to 9.Set the Bass at 10,the Mid at 15 and Treble at 10 and a half.The result is very shredable.Now play with the sound adding delay or adjusting the reverb.oh, and heres a cheap demo of the sound if you want oneloop.mp3EDIT: Added nspg file called "HeavyGit" according to your tutorial based on 1st quarter ADMIN

post_content: Please leave your comments and critism.

title: arppeggio sort of sound on EX
post_content: Nope the Ex doen't have an apreggiator but there is a way to make more of an illusion of one.First tweak a synth patch to reapeat mode.Set the mod envelope Realease/ decay nob to 206 ms.And the amp envelope Release /decay nob to zero.Turn the Freq mod envolope to 7.5.Now turneththe ringmod effect on and set it to 15.Turn on phaser 2 , adjust the amount to 95 and set the rate/tempo to 15.This result isnt  very convincing , but it can be a nice background to a sound.Different timings take some chalenging tweaking

title: RE: arppeggio sort of sound on EX
post_content: Hi Titanium,great idea! I have been experimenting to get some Pseudo ARP before with wahwah, tremolo the MOD ENV etc., but without great success. Using the RingMOD is a great idea.I tried to replicate what you suggest and I'd say for a keyboard without Arpeggiator, the result is not too bad. Let me know if that is what you had in mind (see the mp3 file) or if I got it wrong somewhere. Kudos Titanium for this patch!!! Really like it!PseudoARP.mp3

post_content: Thnx for the answer Johannes. I have bought a used nord stage compact and it's my first sinth. I have some problem with choose sounds and i don't know clearly the organs.. title: RE: Sound of "Bohemian like you"?
post_content: Hi,no problem. It takes some time to get to know all the sound sources of your instrument. For the particular song, I would select just the Organ section of your Nord Stage, switch on the (on the very left) Leslie Emulation on LOW (lights slowly oscillating), set the Organ to Hammond /B-3 Mode, and use the drawbuttons to adjust the sound. The numbers I mentioned is just an example for the drawbar settings you might consider (see here for more on classical Hammond Drawbar settings:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-stage ... 20settings), but its best to do it by ear. If you have any question, have a look at the Organ part of the Manual or post back!Cheers

title: RE: How to use patches in NS EX?
post_content: BrunoM wrote:Hello guys, I´m from Brazil and I just bought a nord stage ex 76. I´ve downloaded some patches here, but how can I put them in my keyboard, using the nord stage manager? or by the system menu on the keyboard? I know it´s a very basic question, but if someone could help me I´ll be very gratefull.Hello BrunoM,Welcome to the forums!You use the Nord Sound Manager (NSM) version 5.58 to download the new program to your instrument.Before doing this, I recommend doing a complete backup of your instrument "this could take 10+ minutes to complete".Once you've done this, then pick a program, or programs to delete, delete it (them) to free up space, then simply drag the new program to the NSM window (programs tab) and it will begin uploading.Cheers, Hanon

post_content: that sounds pretty ok to me. Only I can't seem to load nss files (NS EX uses .nspg right?)any short tutorials on how to create that sound?

title: RE: handclap on NS EX
post_content: heisterkamp wrote:that sounds pretty ok to me. Only I can't seem to load nss files (NS EX uses .nspg right?)any short tutorials on how to create that sound?Hello heisterkamp,the .nss file is just the synth patch.The .nspg would be the entire program patch which would include any layered instruments such as piano, organ, and synth.You can load the synth patch with the Nord Sound Manager software (NSM).In the main NSM window, choose the 'synth" tab, delete one of the existing presets "that you don't want"...better yet, choose upload to copy it to a safe location on your computer for future use, then delete it from NSM.Then simply drag the new preset "Prophet 5 claps.nss" to the vacant location.Just in case this doesn't work out for you, here is the .nspg fileSynth Claps   H.nspg(426 Bytes) Downloaded 692 timesCheers, Hanon

title: RE: Herbie Hancock - Chameleon synth bass
post_content: I'd use that, AMP1 a bit of overdrive and a bit of room reverb, as well as some more treble and bass (mid left 0)For a similar thing, I set up a sawtooth wave with the 12dB/octave filter, a fair bit of resonance and an enveloped "fall off" so you get a real farty sound, then if you get the maximum porno sound, you then go through the waves until you get to the RESO lot in the WAVE bank and then it's just fartyness off the scale!

title: Choir
post_content: Hi,I am currently looking for a good choir synth patch. I found one on the yahoo group but it is a SysEX File and whenever I try to transfer it it transfers it fine (using MIDIOX) but the sound does not appear on the Stage. According to the Manual, it should just overwrite the currently selected Patch no? In any case the patch remains unchanged while MIDI in general works just fine and the MIDI LED blinks when I transfer the SysX File. Anyone an idea how to solve the problem?r has another choir patch / or could "convert" the File into a NS Program/Synth patch??Thanks, Johannes

title: RE: Choir
post_content: Hi Johannes,Lately, I've been going through the "U files" Unanswered posts, in an effort to give an answer.Here's the sysex patch loaded and re-saved as .nss fileMaleVoiceAhh.nssMaleVoiceAhh converted from sysex(53 Bytes) Downloaded 615 timesI can only speculate as to why your instrument didn't load the sysex version, and tell you what I did to get it to load on mine.It's possible that your instrument sysex id was set to something other than "all".In the sysex file, the device id is 7F hex or 127 decimal.I used a program calledBome's Send SXrather than midi-ox,but I had similar results withMIDI-OXCheers, Hanon

title: RE: Choir
post_content: Hey Hanon,thanks a lot for the great job in answering all "open" posts!! Really appreciated!!!Also for the patch, dunno while it didn't work for me, but thanbks for converting!Regarding its sound, hmm, its probably as far as one can get for choir sounds without samples!Cheers Johannes

title: RE: Choir
post_content: Johannes wrote:Hey Hanon,thanks a lot for the great job in answering all "open" posts!! Really appreciated!!!Also for the patch, dunno while it didn't work for me, but thanks for converting!Regarding its sound, hmm, its probably as far as one can get for choir sounds without samples!Cheers JohannesHi Johannes,I was avoiding comment on the actual sound.IMHO,I think the sysex sound may be useful, but the factory sound (pad 28 Vox Humana 1 AD) seems like a much better choir building block.I think Åke Danielson has a great ear, and great programming instincts.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Memory expand
post_content: Totmusic wrote:I´ll get one to, eventually, but for now, could you plz share your favorites with us?Hello Totmusic,I'm glad you asked.I use the Grand Imperial Bdorf LRG for solo classic work.the Grand Lady D LRG for Ballads, accompaniment, and small jazz ensembles.the Studio Grand 1 (Yamaha C7 Conservatory Grand) LRG for rock gigs.the Electric Grand CP80 for Genesis, Gabriel, and Journey covers.But these choices are only what I've come to be satisfied with, other musicians' results may vary ;)I also cheat and use my NE3 for some extra piano memory and play it via my NSEx hammer action keyboard,In my NE3 I have the Grand Lady D LRG, Studio Grand 2 (Yamaha C7 Conservatory Grand), and a couple of Uprights loaded.IMHO,there's no real "perfect" piano sound, I've been searching for 30+ years and still haven't found it.There's what you like, what you don't like, and the musical genre that it either works, or doesn't work with.Tastes in pianos are a very personal and individual thing. This probably why so many different ones are manufactured.I've had hundreds of instruments throughout my career. The digital piano that I'm most satisfied with is Nord.My Korg M3-88 never leaves the house.Just my 2 centavos...Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Patches D70
post_content: Hello Rene,As promised, here are a few samples from my Roland D-70.The demo was recorded using my NE3 to play the samples.The first sound is MondoPoly, the next is Ghosties, and the last is LeadSynth1.LeadSynth1 missed the mark quite a bit because there was no way to properly reproduce the portamento, aftertouch filter sweep and vibrato on my NE3.These are all sampled from my instrument and not from any existing recordings, or any existing licensed sample sets.These are freely shared for use by NordUserForum members for performance and recordings and license is hereby granted for said usage, but not to be sold as an individual sample, samples, or part of a sample collection.If you find these useful, please consider donating to the operation of this great forum so that it will continue to be available to you, and others in the future:http://www.norduserforum.com/donate.phpD70_samples_demo.mp3D70_MondoPoly.nsmp(2.67 MiB) Downloaded 2619 timesD70_Ghosties.nsmp(2.83 MiB) Downloaded 2117 timesD70_LeadSynth1.nsmp(1.57 MiB) Downloaded 2322 timesI used aMOTU UltraLite MK3for audio I/O andAudacityto record the .wav files.It seems as if the Nord Sample Manager software only works with samples recorded at 44.1kHz.I'd have liked to use a much higher sample rate.I hope you find some of these useful.Cheers, Hanon

title: Skylines synth - CAMEL
post_content: Hi all,this is my first contribution to the Patches Forum. Not a great or difficult synth to program, but I'm decided to learn how to exploit the synth partition and had to start somewhere.Here's the original song, the synth starts at 1:48:[youtube][/youtube]Here are the preview and the program:Skylines.mp3Skylines.nspg(426 Bytes) Downloaded 759 timesTo obtain the vibrato, move the modulation wheel to taste....BUT NOW I HAVE A QUESTION: how can I achieve in the NS Synth the great effect that can be seen at the end of the solo in the following live video at 3:15?[youtube][/youtube]thanks in advanceRamon

title: RE: Skylines synth - CAMEL
post_content: Excellent programming and playing Ramon!I don't think that the wild vibrato at the end of the live solo will be possible with the synth section of the Nord because certain parameters are somewhat fixed and limited "maximum modulation depth being one of them".Peter Bardens, the keyboardist of that era, was one of my favorites.It's interesting that he chose a square waveform in the live solo.Without patches, or presets on the Minimoog, the sound was liable to be different with each show.Thanks for sharing, you're awesome!

title: RE: Skylines synth - CAMEL
post_content: thank you for your kind words!!I've also tried to achieve the wild vibrato with the phaser 2 and it sounds quite good on the wild side, but I couldn't make it sound good in the no-vibrato parts.BTW, I hear a keyclick in the patch, starting each note, and couldn't get rid of. Any idea where is it produced?Ramon

title: RE: Skylines synth - CAMEL
post_content: mon8169 wrote:thank you for your kind words!!I hear a keyclick in the patch, starting each note, and couldn't get rid of. Any idea where is it produced?RamonHi Ramon,You're welcome. I love your handmade drawbars controller.The click is the filter being modulated by a rather sharp envelope.If you'll reduce the "LP Filter, Freq control, mod envelope" setting to zero then adjust the LP Filter frequency to suit tastes, that should eliminate the click.As an alternate solution; slightly increase the amp envelope attack time, that should do the trick also.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Skylines synth - CAMEL
post_content: that was it, the mod evelope and velocity sensing!many thanks!Ramon

title: On the run sequence on the Nord Stage
post_content: here is the On The Run patch I made for the NS, a preview of using it is here:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NT4wA3Ap_pk[youtube][/youtube]HOW TO USE IT:First of all you must keep the sustain pedal at all times, that is how you latch the sequence.Experiment around with the synth on the Panel B, the on withthe pulse wave, and try to figure out how the repeating works using the attack and rel/decay of the mod env.Then just play the notes and make the decay faster. it may go out of tempo a bit, but its not so important.The synth on panel A is just one made to play one note and just fool around with the controls, moving any of the knobs of the osc group makes it shift the pitch, which is rather cool, but the timbre knob is kinda steppyHOPE YOU ENJOY!!!!On The Run.mp3

title: RE: On the run sequence on the Nord Stage
post_content: thanks man...

title: Key Velocity Nords Stage EX Pad/Synth
post_content: Hi All,Can someone tell me how to turn on the key velocity on the Synth part of the Nord? It doesn't matter how hard I push the keys it all the same volume.......I hope someone can help me.

title: RE: Key Velocity Nords Stage EX Pad/Synth
post_content: Hi Fraber and welcome to the forum.Just turn the knob that says FREQ CONTROL above it and VELOCITY below it.Remember also to not have the other knob, that says FREQ below it on max.The way it will work is, that the harder you press the keys, the higher the frequency cutoff will be.Hope it helps.Cbas

title: RE: Key Velocity Nords Stage EX Pad/Synth
post_content: Fraber, to make volume level respond to velocity you have to push the Shift button and move clockwise the Amp Env knob until the red light (env vel) goes on, then you move the knob in the position you want for the attack of the sound.Diego

title: RE: Key Velocity Nords Stage EX Pad/Synth
post_content: Hi Diego! Thanks a lot it works great! My problem is solved. And Cbas also thanks for your reply

title: Request: patch for Piece of the Rock by Mothers Finest
post_content: Hi there,I'm a newbie on this forum, and  a very proud owner of the Nord Stage 88 since one week.Since I am new with the instrument i'm not yet very familiar with all the possibilities, especially the synth section.In our band we play the song "Piece of the Rock" by Mothers Finest. I am trying to get this fat synth sound, but so far I haven't found the sound I'm looking for. Is there anyone out there who has tried this before ?Thanks in advance,Marc Linssen

title: RE: Request: patch for Piece of the Rock by Mothers Finest
post_content: Hi Marc,Is this close enough?It's a deceptively simple sound, but difficult to properly reproduce because MF keyboardist Mike Keck used a Minimoog for it on the recording, and live shows.I'll hold off uploading the patch until I get a thumbs up.... Or down:(minimoog oct 1.nssminimoogish octave synth 1(53 Bytes) Downloaded 538 timesSynth patchMF POTR SYNTH  1.nspgStage patch for dual synths POTR(426 Bytes) Downloaded 681 timesStage patch using dual synths 2 octaves apart.POTR_intro.mp3This sound requires a synth patch to be layered with it's self, 1 an octave down, 1 an octave up for an overall separation of two octaves. The filter is wide open with plenty of buzzy harmonics.The swimmy sound on the original recording actually sounds like a mutron bi-phase rather than the filter resonance "emphasis" being modulated by LFO.In the stage patch I used the phas2 effect for this.Putting this quick little patch together reminded me of what I miss from the Minimoog, and most real analog synths: That "take over the mix" huge-ness of sound.

title: RE: Request: patch for Piece of the Rock by Mothers Finest

title: The Doors, Alabama Song
post_content: Hello people,Our band is going to do a Doors tribute very soon and I am looking for the sounds of Alabama Song (Whiskey Bar). For the left hand in the beginning I use en F. Rhodes bass. title: Pink Floyd Sound
post_content: Hi,since in my band we considered just for fun playing some old Pink Floyd songs, I started to work on some patched trying to emulate Richard Wright's playing on organ and Synth. While I really love their sounds, its hard to get close unfortunately.So far I did a patch for Shine on your crazy diamond which took me a while but no I am fairly satisfied. In general, I find the organ part to nail any given sound quite easily while to get the Lead Synth is hard, its a nice warm trumpet-like MiniMoog and I am still working on getting the typical trumpet like attack at the beginning. Also I am aiming at getting more PF sounds but will take some time...EDIT: Just worked a bit mor on it, including triedto get the kind of water drop like falling pattern at the beginning of the LP Wish You were here version right, so had to use two patches since I needed 3 Synthsshine_on_intro.mp3

title: RE: Pink Floyd Sound
post_content: Hi,true, actually, when recoprding, I cheated a little bit in audacity ;-).Anyhow, I was working more on this sound anyhow and finally after some tweaking I finally got what I would call my best guess for the Crazy Diamond in ONE patch:Panel A: Organ for the Pad (left split), Moog Lead (right split)Panel B: the dripping sound at the Intro. (only on the Album Version on "Wish you were here")Now the good thing with the Panels is that you can switch between Panels while the sound you sustain with the Pedal does not stop.So hold the G Octave on Panel A, slowly turn the MOD wheel to increase volume, Hold the SUSTAIN Pedal down. Then switch to Panel B, play a slow slide over the whole key range, switch back, hold the G Octave again and start with the Synth Line.Feel free to further work on it if you want, in particularI recall having more convincing Mini Moog Settings but I lost them.CrazyDiamond.mp3

title: 3 split organ
post_content: Hello,Is it possible to create een patch with 3 different B3 organ settings? For the song Hottentot by John Scofield I am looking for: 1. the sound to play the Bes7-5 chord throughout the song 2. a percussive sound that plays the same line as the guitar does 3. a sound to play the descending chords from the bridgde.Now I couldn't figure out to do this with use of virual tonewheel engine for all 3 sections, so for the descending chords I used a digital organ-wave but of course that doesn't sound as good.Can this be done or is it impossible since there are only 2 virtual tonewheel engines in the Stage EX?

title: RE: 3 split organ
post_content: hi Kareldejong.moving your post to the General Discussion Forum instead...on the NS you can simultaniously play two drawbar registers. you can split them on the internal keybed or layering them (using both PANEL A and PANEL B). you can also play them on both the internal and an external keybed, using the DUAL KB mode. the two different organ settings shares the same organ type and leslie/drive settings.youcan notuse the organ engine 3 times within the samePROGRAM. what youcan dois change the registry settings by using aMORPHfunction.hope this helps.-------------------EDIT: ooops! i made a typo here. one can't share two organs over one PANEL. it always has to be two. text changed.

title: RE: 3 split organ
post_content: I had been puzzling over the same issue, how to get three organ sounds in a single program - thanks for your advice Henrik !

title: RE: 3 split organ
post_content: The way I would do it:We only have two hands, so we only need to play to sounds at a time. I would do a split organ patch with one organsound on panel A and one organsound on panel B. The third organ sound I would put on the "preset II" button in the organ section. I would put this sound in the panel that I don't use while playing this sound.So if we need 1. bass organ sound 2. chord organ sound 3. melodic/solo organ sound:I would put 1. in Panel A, and put 2. in Panel B and 3. on the preset II in Panel B. So at all times I could play the bass in my left hand while playing either chords or solo in my right hand.Alternately you could do two seperate patches next to each other. Both having the same bass sound on panel A, but having different sounds on panel B.I don't know if this is what you wanted. I can see a problem with this if you need to play the two sounds right after another alot. Then you could not switch fast enough to pull it off. But that would not be possible to do on the Stage as far as I can see. Unless you would use a synth organ sound in a 3-split as mentioned.Have fun.

title: RE: 3 split organ
post_content: Thank you very much for the advice. This is indeed the way I have soveld this 'problem'.Before I was using a piano (yamaha cp300) and a Nord C1 on top. At the moment I am figuring out if I can play everything I need on just the Stage EX. But I don't 'dare' to sell the C1 yet as we do a lot of improvising (blues band) and then it's handy to always have a organ ready while playing piano, without having to swith settings.Regards, Karel

title: RE: 3 split organ
post_content: Cbas wrote:The third organ sound I would put on the "preset II" button in the organ section.Cbas is right! this is probably the best way to do it. when using the PRESET II button you are not only changing the registry setting, but also the vibrato and percussion settings are stored within thePROGRAM. and the vib/perc settings can't be changed using aMORPHfunction...

title: RE: 3 split organ
post_content: Cbas wrote:The C1 has a very good Organ sound though. Much better than the Stage, so I don't know if I would sell it, if it was me. But only relying on one keyboard is nice.Okay, so there really IS a different 'tonewheel engine' in the Stage than in the C1? That explains why I got a totally different sound when I was copying all the drawbar settings I had programmed in the C1 to the Stage. The C1 sounds warmer in my opinion. But then again the Stage gives you more possibilies like the Compressor: 'cause when you decide you want to throw in some Overdrive on the spot your soundengineer almost can't handle the volume on the C1 whereas on the Stage you can keep things within certain limits using the Compressor. And then there is the almost irritating key click on the C1. Me, and several others have asked Nord for a software update to control this keyclick but they answered me it wasn't necessary. 'You can just turn down the treble' they answered me (which would 'ruin' the rest of your sound of course). But, surprise... on the C2 and the Stage there IS the possibilty to control the amount of key click.)

title: RE: 3 split organ
post_content: kareldejong wrote:Cbas wrote:The C1 has a very good Organ sound though. Much better than the Stage, so I don't know if I would sell it, if it was me. But only relying on one keyboard is nice.Okay, so there really IS a different 'tonewheel engine' in the Stage than in the C1? That explains why I got a totally different sound when I was copying all the drawbar settings I had programmed in the C1 to the Stage. The C1 sounds warmer in my opinion. But then again the Stage gives you more possibilies like the Compressor: 'cause when you decide you want to throw in some Overdrive on the spot your soundengineer almost can't handle the volume on the C1 whereas on the Stage you can keep things within certain limits using the Compressor. And then there is the almost irritating key click on the C1. Me, and several others have asked Nord for a software update to control this keyclick but they answered me it wasn't necessary. 'You can just turn down the treble' they answered me (which would 'ruin' the rest of your sound of course). But, surprise... on the C2 and the Stage there IS the possibilty to control the amount of key click.)Yeah the sounds are definitly different.The Electro 2 was the first organ engine.The Stage got the same organ engine as the Electro 2 at first, but got improved overdrive and key-click.Then they made the C1 which was big improvement on the Stage's organ engine in my opinion.The Electro 3 got the same organ engine as the C1.And then they made the C2, which should be a mild improvement on the C1(haven't tried the C2 yet).I can understand what you mean about controling the keyclick. I actually thought that was implemented in the C1. Seems very weird not to include that feature.

title: The Who - Baba O'Riley/Won't get fooled again
post_content: Hi,recently I did some experimenting with Organ+Trenolo and Phasers and figured it would be nice to create the famous sound Pete Townsend used for these two songs.For a description of the original sound seehttp://www.thewho.net/whotabs/equip-baba.htm.While he originally used a processed (thfough a VCF) Lowrey Berkshire Deluxe TBO-1 Organ, the basic sound should be managble with either the F- or V-Type Organ of the Stage, using the WahWah on the Organ and a Tremolo for the rythmical patterns, I am not sure if one can get the somewhat random pattern the Lowrey was able to produce in the Marimba-Repeat mode (see the description above).In general, I really love the Organs processed through some synths which was heavily used in that era and the Stage with its Synth section plus great organ emulation should be a great keyboard to replicaste these sounds.So I will put my first try here soon, but if yomeone already had to come up with a similar sound, feel free to share it here!!cheers, johannesEDIT: finally got to upload the first try:Wont get fooled.nspg(426 Bytes) Downloaded 918 timesListen:wont-get-fooled-again.mp3

title: RE: B3 organ patches
post_content: You could try layering the organ with a synth sound to try and get the harmonics you need. Perhaps one of the digital waveforms might be suitable - for example, something like Digital waveform 3. Unfortunately, you can't run a synth through the Leslie at the same time as the Hammond, but it might get you close enough.Regardsleo1000red

title: RE: B3 organ patches

title: RE: Custom Sounds
post_content: Sorry, but playing custom samples on the Nord Stage is impossible as of now.BUT! The Nord Electro CAN. You should consider it. It has a superb organ engine (same as the C2, the NS has theC1), it also has the ability to load custom samples, and the very good Nord Stage pianos, EPs, Clavs, etc.But keep in mind that the NE3 does not have: multitimbrality nor synth engine. But you do not need the synth engine having samples. Nord does provide free synth samples for their NE3 and NW users.If you need to have a synth, a killer combo would be pairing the NE3 with a mopho keyboard and later expand it with a Tetra. I think it could be cheaper.... but you do not have the convinient "all you need" in just one place...Anyways, Hope I helped you decide on what to get :DGustavo

title: The sample-and-hold-to-pitch computer sound
post_content: Hi,the other day I was reading this nice list of "famous" synth soundshttp://www.synthmania.com/Famous%20Sounds.htmwhich includes on No.2 the famous sound everyone thinks immediately of the "Sound" of a computer. It basically is a sample-and-hold module assigned to pitch to create this quasi-random pitch pattern. Now the Nord Stage does not have a sample-and-hold function so I though of a different way to kind of recreate this sound.I use the noise generator with maximum Resonance to create the approx. sine wave and let velocity control the frequency at a very high amount (around 80%).Now play some random notes, you will probably never get the same velocity and hence you get a random pitch sequence.Leaving KeyTrack still on gives you some discretion of the broad "range" of the random pitch.Sample-n-hold JE.mp3PS: If you select MOD control to Filter instead of Velocity and play around with the MOD ENV, you get this laser sword kind of sound...

title: DX-7
post_content: There are many good piano samples available for the nordstage. But I still miss a really good DX-7 sample. Does anybody know, Clavia is planning this?Juergen

title: RE: DX-7
post_content: Hi Juergen,dunno I get your question right, but you know  that the Nord Stage is not a Rompler in the classical sense nor able to playback Samples such as the Nord Wave or NE3.I agree that it s unfortunate that no samples can be loaded in the NS (from the Nord Sample Librar or something else, the new Chamberlin Samples are really making me want to be able to do so even more!!!) But I guess that will never happen.Moreover, the Synth Engine is partly a (ssmall) FM synthesizer (3ops) so basically you can /have to create your own FM patches that will at least technically be similar to some stuff that the DX7 did. Also there are some FM waveforms in the Synth section, but they als require that you use Filter, EGs etc. to get the sound you want. I created some FM patches but not really happy with them and did not find any nice patches out there to download, nor on this website,so if anyone got some nice DX7 emulation patches, please share!!!!Cheers,Fred

title: RE: Drawbar Settings Request: Hush
post_content: Yeah Hush is a great song. Deep Purple rocks for (cl)tonewheeler.I found a quite OK Jon Lord patch based on a split setting (different volumes mainly), and using the AmpSim (not Leslie) cranked up quite a bit and a similar drawbar setting as the one suggested.It works fine for Highway Star but I am no 100% satisfied, but will put my final result also here, but would be interesting to see different approaches to rock Jon's solo parts!Happy Friday, Happy Keyboarding!!EDIT: Just finished my patch to use for Deep Purple Covers, and I found 888000008 to harh at the higher end and hence used 888000003. Plus overdrive from the Jazz Chorus simulation, the Leslie w/o any overdrive (Jon uses it in Hush I think while it is absent in many other songs). See if you like it or let me know if you can nail it even more!! (And sorry for the bad playing, was a bit in a rush)jonlord.mp3

title: Tronish Strings & Plucky Bass
post_content: Hi,alwas on the quest for interesting new sounds to get some new ideas, just browsed the website of Philipp Koltsov (http://www.koltsov.biz/patches.htmlwho has a RAR file containing around fifty patches for the Nord Stage (http://www.koltsov.biz/nordstagepatches.rar). While many are the ones from the Yahoo group or others I already knew, there were some interesting ones, in particular two synth based (possibly also from somewhere else but don't remember the original source).One String patch that sounds rather Mellotronish (IIRC I've heard it somewhere before but not sure).:tronish_strings.mp3Tronnish Strings.nspg(426 Bytes) Downloaded 914 timesThe other interesting patch I found was a Plucky Bass good for emulating an accoustic bass when needed:Plugged_Bass.mp3Plucky Bass.nspg(426 Bytes) Downloaded 930 times

title: RE: Flute
post_content: Hello everyone!I have come up with a flute patch quite similar to the one originally posted. But the main difference is the color, which is basicly the patch with the frequency shifted higher. Also, I dont really use a blow sound, since in real life, when recording wind isntruments, you want the instrument itsefl to be heard and not the player´s blowing at it ;). Doing this also frees up space for an extra synth sound .BTW I am also working in some string patches, but none are quite good, I will post when I get a good one.Gustavo

title: Keane CP-70 sound
post_content: Hi,I am currently trying to get a as close as possible sound of Keane since I have to do a cover of some of there songs.Basically, I really like the CP-80 piano in the stage, but it is missing some effects, as far as I guess some chorus, very little reverv and probably a bit of compression, but have not yet get a completely satisfying sound such as in "somewhere only we know", anyone tried something like that??Seeing these guys live, it would apparently be nice to have a "real" CP-x0 in the grand piano form, but the Stage's beautiful as well ;-)thanks, Joebtw, Keane's KB shouldn't have problems getting respect as keyboard player (nice discussion on this topic here:http://forums.musicplayer.com/ubbthread ... /2071135/1)

title: RE: Keane CP-70 sound
post_content: I recently had the chance to play a real CP-70. I'd say it is the pure CP-x0 sound with just a hint of chorus. His foot rarely gets of the pedal, wich causes a lot of sympathetic resonance. And I guess he has a good preamp with lots of headroom. I don't think clavia implemented pedal down samples in the CP-80 library.Imagine how nice the Stage would sit on top of the CP-70! ;o)

title: White Room (Cream)
post_content: Hi, this is my White Room preset, hope you'll enjoy it.Panel A :B3 organ with saturation. fast leslie on aftertouch. susped is on for easy switching between panelssaturated e-piano for bigger basssynth based on velocity : doens't trigger if you play gentlyPanel Bpiano + little pad + little organworks fine with a V-Type organ, but you'll have to lower the organ, otherwise you won't hear anything.tell me what you think, what organ do you prefer ? (don't comment the playing...) how can I improve ?White room (B3).mp3White room (V-Type).mp3file recorded with Garage Bandps : sorry for the bad playing.. just replaying piano after years of abstinence

title: RE: White Room (Cream)
post_content: Johannes wrote:And in general with the B3 I would like to find a way that the Leslie starts a bit slower and takes longer to reach full speed, but dunno if that is possible with the STAGE at all.I guess with that patch you can easily cut a guitarist playing Cream ;-)JYou can set the rotor acceleration speed in the sound menu. You can also manually control the speed change in the rotor by using morph. Hope this answers your question.

title: RE: White Room (Cream)
post_content: Excellent! That must have slipped through my fingers when reading the manual. Set it to "slow" now it feels (for me) much more natural. Since I control it with the Sustain Ped cannot use the Morph feature so far until I get a decent pedal. But thanks a lot for pointing this out!!! Joe

title: RE: White Room (Cream)
post_content: question : my expression pedal is set to swell mode, so if i morph the leslie speed on the experssion pedal, I would have the lowest organ level with the slowiest leslie speed.other question : if I use damper pedal for leslie speed, how do I do with sustain on piano with an organ in the background ?

title: RE: White Room (Cream)
post_content: jpcaruana wrote:question : my expression pedal is set to swell mode, so if i morph the leslie speed on the experssion pedal, I would have the lowest organ level with the slowiest leslie speed.That's true, probably there is no way to get "everything at the same time", either get another expression pedal for the Leslie, or don't use Swell, or use Damper for Laslie (or anyother morphing setup with Modulation wheel or Aftertouch)jpcaruana wrote:other question : if I use damper pedal for leslie speed, how do I do with sustain on piano with an organ in the background ?What I do, if the Piano is more in the foreground, leave it as it is, e.g. end up with Leslie FAST always when on sustain, OR -if the Organ is what's more important, I switch of the Sustain Pedal for the Piano sound and just add a bit of reverb/hall to it and that does the job for me.But actually I am thinking of getting another expression type pedal as an additional control to achieve this. Anyone knows the best to get? The best woud be a combined Expression/Sustain one, meaning two pedals in one unit next to eachother. Im sure I saw it ones, but cannot remember which brand it was...
